reviewText:
This is a free text based experience that just has you clicking hyperlinks as you would a webpage. I can't really call it a game since I don't think the point is to entertain you. It was originally a website and this is just the web-kit version of the site put on Steam. I'm not sure it will help anyone with depression, so much as it lets people with depression think, no you are not alone (the player, not the character 'You'). Other people feel the way you do.

The basic gameplay in Depression Quest is that you will read through things (You is the player character that you will play) and then make a choice of what to do (click a hyperlink).

It sets a story and gives you background information on things. You have everything going for you, a significant other, a circle of friends, a day job. Your girlfriend, Alex is supportive of who you are and understands you. That's more than some people have in real life, but it illustrates you can have everything and yet depression still affects you. At least the characters in the game are supportive of you and not questioning why you have depression or does depression exist or are you just lazy? Its almost like everyone accepts you, but you are the one with a problem that doesn't accept yourself. Its all inward in this experience. You make enough money to support yourself, so money isn't the issue, but money is never a discussion or a reason to the depression, its just all you.

Below each life choice, Depression Quest bluntly tells you that you are not in therapy, nor taking medication for depression, you are just dealing with it. The 'happy' or 'logical' choices are always crossed out forcing you to select the sad choices such as, 'watch TV, work on a project (Depression Quest) or crawl into bed.'

The big thing that I take away from this is everyone around you (the player character) really cares about you. It also seems like there's no way out. Maybe there would be a way out to happiness with diet, less beer, soaking up some sun so your body can make vitamin D or a life change, but that's never explored, you are just suffering from depression and forced to live that way. Depression Quest brings up minor what ifs, such as going back to school or finding a better job might help... but well there's risk. Those statements are never followed up. You have no choice to change things in your life (the character's).

You see the character get worse and worse with no help in sight. Almost as if the entire point of this is to make you the player depressed (which is different than depression). Crossing out logical happy choices for depressing ones. This is a quick experience that finishes after maybe 2 dozen pages of text. I quickly played through it three times and it felt like while there are multiple endings, it didn't feel like I wanted to take the time to see them all. Like reading and carefully selecting my choices leads to more reading to endings that I didn't feel were satisfying. It was too quick of an experience to feel nothing more than a brief diversion. Someone did write me on how to get to the 'good ending' where you are allowed to get help, but with so many choices and endings, I found it difficult to even get the good ending with someone telling me how to achieve it. Again, the happy ending just didn't feel good or satisfying. Maybe that's depression in a nutshell or maybe that's poor writing.

To anyone suffering from depression, there is always help. There are always people willing to help and you are never alone. *hug*

reviewText: Point blank: I think this game fails at what it set out to do. It doesn't make the user understand depression at all. In fact, it's just the story of some overpriviledged guy too stuck in his head. Nothing awful actually happens to the character. The player isn't made to sympathize with him in any way. Instead it just comes off as Make the right decision and get moderately better". Actual depression is nothing like that. It just fails on all levels to capture just how dreary and dreadful the world actually looks when you've got depression. There's no sense of hopelessness or despair. The name itself "Depression Quest" is utterly uncreative and unimaginative as well."

reviewText:
As someone who has been diagnosed with clinical depression at the age of 17 (now 22), as well as living with a diagnosed manic depressive older brother and formerly suicidal sister, I felt like this game, Depression Quest, could help me gain stability in parts of my life where I lack.
As it turns out, it is nothing short of insulting. Depression Quest takes the impossible  weight and drain of simply feeling /bad/, and reduces it to a rather whiney, irritating and self-absorbed narrative. It /then/ takes the raging emotional battles and incredible fears cloud rational thought and displays them as so many single-line responses. I KNOW WHAT TO DO. I KNOW A SEEING THERAPIST IS THE CORRECT CHOICE. I KNOW LYING BACK IN BED IS THE WRONG CHOICE. It's not about what you should do, it's about how in the heck to conquor all that negativity and emotional drag to get anywhere. It's about how to consciously break those cycles of self-hating thoughts and stop those feelings before they happen. Bear in mind these are only my objections to the depiction of depression as a disorder.

Depression Quest as a game? I have literally read popup books that were more interactive, and I use the term correctly. The 1996 classic Wishbone and the Amazing Odyssey was 100 times the game this one could ever hope to be, and it had a neato dog. I tried to think of games that came close to being as frustrating to play, aside from personally offensive, and I counted to None! None games! Ah ah aaaahhh!

reviewText:
I got this game a while ago, as you see I didn't spend very long in it, but it was long enough. I don't know anything about the whole controversy seeing as how I tend to stay away from BS, but this game is bad.

I have actual PTSD, from being in the military and from having witnessed murder of my brother at a very young age and I can tell you that Depression is absolutely nothing like this. This game is terrible at depicting depression. If you want to know what actual depression is like, just imagine being in a deep hole and not having the strength and will power to climb out as you're having dirt shoveled onto you and being buried alive. That's the easiest way I can describe it, but even that does no real justice. This game did the very thing that is almost impossible to do, offend me. It offends me, because of how terribly it misrepresents actual suicidal depression. That's coming from a suicide attempt survivor.

P.S No one cares about your special snowflake syndrome.

reviewText:
Regardless of my views of the developer, I decided to play and review Depression Quest honestly. And while it tries to be an interesting interactive fiction game, it suffers from several misteps that ultimately made me feeling like DQ was poorly done and pointless to play.
The first thing was the music. I understand something upbeat and jazzy may not have been appropriate, but the same three or so bars of minor chord piano music just got annoying far too quickly. I would have liked an option to turn it off.
As for the gameplay, it's completely told through text with decisions at the bottom, like Choose Your Own Adventure books. The writer was of average quality. It wasn't horrible, but it wasn't exactly Virginia Wolfe either. The choices frustrated me, however, by having you frequently unable to select more positive choices over more negative ones. I get that this was to simulate the 'it will never get better' feelings of depression, but there is a difference between feeling it will never improve and actively being unable to make a positive choice in your life, even ones like seeing a therapist. When I was depressed, they couldn't make me NOT see one.
On the bottom of your screen, you have boxes that discuss your condition in regards to depression, if you're in therapy, and whether you take medication or not. It seemed to me, though, that no matter how well the little box said you were doing, the story never reflected that through a brighter outcome (until the ending at least) or by letting you make more positive choices. I understand depression is a struggle, but I never felt any sort of real sense of progression beyond the game occasionally telling me I was with a token pat on the back.
I also question whether this game belongs on Steam. I know it used to be a browser game, but it still looks and plays exactly like a browser game. Why does Steam have to be involved? In the end, I would not have played this game if it wasn't free.
4/10

reviewText:
I'm not even sure what to say about this thing. It's just boring and is entirely all reading.

Depression Quest is a very, very basic wall of text formatted into several linear paths about depression. Literally, wall of text after wall of text without any visuals other than grainy photographs at the top and a really depressing audio (similar to Minecraft's music). The story is written in a way that makes you feel like you're living a dead-end life without any motivation to go on. A bad event comes after bad event. Think of the game like a text-based version of The Walking Dead.

Don't even bother trying this game." If you really wanted to read up on depression

reviewText: As someone with depression, this game was almost like a slap in the face. Each person deals with depression differently; when I feel it come on, I know to get out and do something to feel better. To have those options in the game scratched out makes the game seem biased to what most people think is depression; lazy, defeated, unhappy for months on end. Really, it was getting hard to play this game. There were problems in how depression was put out in this game. This isn't a game to play if you have experienced depression; this is sort of a mockery to ways of dealing with depression and posting this negative view of people with depression.\nLastly, I'd like to add that this isn't a quest. Depression isn't a quest that someone goes through. It's a real life problem that many people suffer with. This game makes it out that there is nothing you can do to make things better, which is even worse to read.\nI would not recommend this game. Not even to someone who is studying depression or personality, mood disorders. It's simply just not good.

reviewText:
My heart goes out to all those who suffer from depression. To you I say: You are so much more important to others than you realize, and there is no shame in needing and getting help. In fact, it is quite heroic of you to be able to admit your weakness to others and to seek to better your situation.

And to those who are depressed, this game" will do absolutely nothing for you. Please go get professional help.

To those who are NOT depressed
date:
you would be better of looking at your group of friends and looking for signs of depression yourself. Skip this "game" entirely. It is a waste of time.

Here are (some) warning signs of Depression and/or Suicide.

•Always talking or thinking about death
•Clinical depression -- deep sadness
hoursPlayed: trouble sleeping and eating -- that gets worse\n•Having a "death wish
voteText:
tempting fate by taking risks that could lead to death, such as driving fast or running red lights
•Losing interest in things one used to care about
•Making comments about being hopeless, helpless, or worthless
•Putting affairs in order, tying up loose ends, changing a will
•Saying things like it would be better if I wasn't here" or "I want out"
•Sudden
helpfulPercent:
unexpected switch from being very sad to being very calm or appearing to be happy
•Talking about suicide or killing one's self
•Visiting or calling people to say goodbye

If you notice that somebody you know or love exhibits some
votesHelpful: any
votesTotal: or all of these symptoms
votesFunny: make sure you say something to them. Offer them your support. Tell somebody else about it
commentsCount: whether it be your high school or college councellor
column16: this person's parents
column17: lover
column18: doctor
column19: etc. Encourage this person to seek professional help. Do NOT expect them to get better on their own

reviewText:
I've been depressed, I don't like talking about it, and I don't like reliving it much less playing a game about it. However, this game fails to deliver by outright not letting you pick activities which you know should pick you up. Because when you are depressed you can choose to do nice things, but those nice things have no effect on your mood whatsover.

This game is unrealistic. What is portrayed is an fake depression which speaks of a lack of self-control and giving up rather than genuine depression. It starts with the stereotype that depressed people lack motivation and works from there. This is wrong. Because depression has nothing to do with what sort of activities you do, and if depression were so simple as that then it would not be a problem.

This is not a good insight into depressed people and I wouldn't recommend it.

reviewText: I stopped playing after three minutes. It was so boring. The screen is a boring shade of white, there are tiny, mundane images at the the top of the screen, and the character didn't feel fleshed out. And the first opportunity I had to make a choice, one of my choices was crossed out. Why the ♥♥♥♥ was it there?! I couldn't select it, so why include it? And then it happened again. And then again. Then I turned it off.\n\nIt felt like one of those choose your own adventure books, except without the fun. And from some of the reviews I've seen from people who completed it, it looks like you can't kill yourself. I'm not the type of person who would intentionally make the character kill themself, but this is a story about depression. Many people with depression commit suicide. The fact that if I made certain choices, the character would kill themself would give me an incentive to play it so that they wouldn't kill themself. I feel like this would work better if it were a dating sim style game (I think they're called interactive novels), where you're the friend or family member of someone with depression, and you have to spend time with them to make them feel better, or they could kill themself. If you can't lose, why play? Not fun at all. Please, remove this from Steam. This isn't a quality game" (it isn't a game)

reviewText: Firstly, I'd like to say that for the amount of content found in this 'game', there is not enough to justify it being a downloadable file. This is the kind of thing that I imagine as a flash game, somewhere on Kongregate or Armor Games where you don't have to keep it on your computer for the fact that it's just about clicking on links and expecting that you chose the right option.\n\nThe music I'd have to say is something I that I myself did not enjoy. The piano was slow, and as far as I could tell it was just a few second loop. The party music would have to be the same in regards to it just being a loop as well. Anyone who is seriously considering trying Depression Quest out, I recommend listening to something on youtube. Under the Sea" from The Little Mermaid made playing this game a fun experience but if you don't like that song
date:
"Hakuna Matata" from The Lion King is a good substitute.

The story itself is something that I personally could not get into. I think it was something to do with being depressed and having a girlfriend named Alex and yeah ... Couldn't get into it.

The fact that certain visable options aren't available in Depression Quest is quite annoying - but I guess that was what was intended when it was being developed. The choices when in your first reading were quite obvious to make
recommended: the train of thought that I had was "Choose the options that make the most sense. Don't focus on work? Hell no. Ignore girlfriend? Hell no. Go to party? Hell YEAH (the most exciting thing that happens until you find out that you're socially awkward even though you HAVE a girlfriend who tries to be intimate with you)"\n\nThinking that you clicked the wrong button and then backtracking to try a different selection of options probably made my experience a drool. Also the fact that choosing different options didn't really change the story all that much was also a bummer

reviewText: This game is very rude towards people like me who deal with depression. I could only sit through 12 minutes of the game before I just shook my head and turned it off to write this review. This character you play as isn't even depressed. They just have no personality. I mean I understand that the creator wants YOU as the player to experience what it's like to go through life and make every day choices while dealing with depression, but this is far from accurate. Maybe it IS like this for some people in worst case scenarios, but still, even depressed people have a personality of some sort. Also, the music was very boring, slow, annoyingly repetitive, and just made me even less interested in playing more of the game. This also applies to the visuals. If I could, I'd rather continue to read it as a visual novel instead. Maybe it gets better the further you play, but until then, I wouldn't recommend playing this game if you have depression. It'll just make you angry at the creator. Even if you don't have depression the overall game so far is very boring.

reviewText: So. Depression Quest. Let me start out by saying that I have had depression. This Game" is not accurate to what depression is like. I say "game" because it's not a game. You can't win nor lose. There is no challenge
date: it's an interactive story. The player has no reason to be depressed

voteText: not even an actual ending. There is no structure. You're just told that you are depressed. The big problem is that the more depressed you get the more limited you are in your choises. My first play I got the worst ending possible for making choices I would realisticly make (or choises I was forced to make). Second play I chose all the good options and nothing really changed. All that happened was that I was less depressed. Nothing major to the story changed. It's less of a story and more of a series of events that sort of connect. The players depression is not realistic whatsoever. You just are depressed for no reason. The problem is that depression is a unique experience for everyone. The basics are the same but the way you deal with it is entirely up to what works for you. I personally shut myself out of the world and worked on writing short stories. I saw a therapist once and hated it. Hated the drugs too. This game makes it too black and white in solutions when really it's all grey. All the player can do to feel better is seek help from others. No way to feel good on your own. Depression for me was not wanting to do anything because it all seems dull. Here it's not wanting to do anything because you're scared. Depression is different for everyone

reviewText:
I played Depression Quest during a time of shortly after having experienced an agonizing break-up. I’m not sure if I was just dealing with grief or if I genuinely was depressed, but I played it hoping I could get an answer. My views are personal as a result.

I found the options for what I could do to be more restricting as the game went on, unnecessarily so to the point where I found it harder to feel immersed in not even being able to try to do some of the things I’d like. Considering I did get medicine and psychiatric help after the devastating end to my long-distance 5 year relationship, I’d have like to know where I would have been for pursuing the same type of help in the game. Some choices in general, particularly the ones that didn’t allow me to talk about my problems, created a greater disconnect between my feelings and the protagonist. In particular, moments where I would simply “choose” not to allow my girlfriend Alex to understand my gnawing feelings that she may to be with someone else--uncannily like my own situation--were extraordinarily frustrating. The fact that the game was becoming linear at the moment I began to actually identify wit the protagonist made this feel like a lost opportunity to me.

Either I’m too wrapped up in my own thoughts to truly empathize with the protagonist, or the developers failed to get a reliably feasible representation of what it means to feel depressed. If it’s the latter, it definitely comes in part from the emphasis on feeling doubtful for anything rather than the actual struggle it takes to pull-through with wanting to save yourself from yourself, which would have made the game give more agency to the player as well as accurately portray how depression is a behemoth of a challenge to feel you can overcome, not a parasite that forces you to make choices you don’t want to.

While the atmosphere left me ready to cry some more, the game wasn’t immersive enough to make the experience feel well-executed. If the game had more focus on allowing choices that are difficult rather than simply disallowing the best options, I would feel completely in the place of this miserable protagonist. In short, the game has potential, but definitely needs refinement before it truly becomes what it sets itself out to be.

reviewText:
This is more of an interactive text experience than a game, and I could liken it some of the old interactive Animorph, Goosebumps and Doctor Who books. Not a lot can be said for it in terms of originality, aside from the fact that nobody to my knowledge, has had the nerve to attempt to make depression into an interactive experience.
I can't help but feel, as much as the supposed intentions of the author as stated at the beggining of the game are all fine and good, that this game comes from a somewhat self centered place. Many of those, and I include myself, who have suffered depression, can often tend to allow their experience to inspire their art and the results can be very satisfying. When I listen to, watch or observe such art, as much as it comes off as sad, it makes me feel joy. This is simply not the case with this game. The author has clearly taken their own experiences and their output has been to make a game that attempts to make other people feel depressed (and I'll place emphasis on the word 'attempt'), rather than to create art and other things that instead express and explore the feeling. It flimsily attempts to impose the feeling upon the viewer rather than present the feeling for the viewer to explore and gain something out of. This gives the game a very self indulgent tone. Self indulgence emanating from any piece of art is not necessarily a bad thing but in this case it feels as though it was completely unchecked by the author, and puts a very bad taste in my mouth.
There really isn't much to speak about in terms of art assets aside from it's sound track, which in my opinion sounds rather tacky and contrived, like the sound track to a depression ad campaign. I must actually say that I feel that the lack of art assets is one of this game's only wise decisions. It's white background and plain text don't overstate the feelings of depression the game is supposed to be imposing on you, which may even compensate for the horrible cheasy music I just mentioned. I can only imagine the overused contrasty pictures and grain effects that could have been chosen to give the game an 'edgy' and 'dark' appearance, and this makes me cringe.
If I could say one other good thing about the game, it would be in the effectiveness of the way in which it makes the player feel hopelessly as though their choices won't matter. Although as stated above, I can't say I appreciate this game's over all approach, and so this slightly impressive mechanic does not even begin to remove the bad taste from my mouth. It should also be mentioned that as a trade off this causes your play through to have little variation as your choices make little difference. No matter what, you tend to wind up back on the same path of the story no matter what choices you make. This only makes a story that is already dull, unoriginal and boring, even less worth while and gives it very little replayability.

In short, I feel that this is a misguided and self indulgent exercise running behind the pretence of being an attempt to reach out to people. It lacks both subtlety and substance, and as an experimental indie game it is dwarved by hundreds of text adventures, point and click adventures and experimental games that have come before it on the levels of creativity, originality, taste and righteous intent, and I can't say it deserves the greenlight it has received.

reviewText:
Depression Quest as described by their website is an “interactive fiction game where you play as someone living with depression. You are given a series of everyday life events and have to attempt to manage your illness, relationships, job, and possible treatment. This game aims to show other sufferers of depression that they are not alone in their feelings, and to illustrate to people who may not understand the illness the depths of what it can do to people.“

Let’s talk about the code behind it… The game is written entirely in web-based languages, such as CSS, HTML, JS etc. It uses a node.js webkit browser to display said pages. There’s no problem with this, but it gave me a bit of a surprise as it doesn’t seem to be too suited to the task at hand. This also gave me a bit of trouble recording the game as I normally use DXTory but it didn’t pick the ‘browser game’ up. In my opinion it would be better coded in a different language as it didn’t even make use of any HTML5 features or any features to access websites which is kind of a waste.

Let’s talk about the game itself, it starts out with some story that didn’t explain why the character was depressed at all, it just seemed to drop you into something you knew nothing about with unfamiliar characters. It asks you some questions on what you would like to do and you can answer, 1, 2, 3 or 4. Except 1 is crossed out for no apparent reason other than to provay the story and lock it down to a more linearised path.
Suddenly after I clicked answer 1 to do work, I am very depressed for no reason other than to tell a story. Next my girlfriend calls me, Alex. It gives me a boring wall of text and 3 options. 1 is of course, as always crossed out because it is the most sensible option of them all - go hang out with your girlfriend and be happy, because that would be way too easy. Now we’re at a party, boring wall of text… and of course, option 1 is crossed off, which is the most sensible with ‘Enthusiastically socialize’. It really confuses me why the most sensible options are crossed off, I thought this story was Depression Quest and not ‘Let’s Try and be as Sad for No Reason and Silly as we can Quest.’

Now we’re back home and our mother has come over for a surprise visit, except we can’t choose the most sensible option again, which is tell her how sad we are, I’ll choose the similar option, number 2.

Sidenote: For some reason the crossed out options and the one just below them are nearly identical… This game is strange…

So, I decide to take up this offer with this person to get a cat as the other options to take the cat but enthusiastically were crossed out..

Anyway, the next scene is the character and their GF talking about some stuff I skipped because it was too long and didn’t seem too relevant to the plot when I speed-read it, anyway, you have options:
1. Tell her how awesome she is, explained with lots of words.
2. Tell her how awesome she is, explained with fewer amount of words.
3. Ask if she is happy with the relationship.
4. Do nothing.

I have decided to chose 3 as it seemed the most sensible. You know I’ve found a pattern; the highest available one seems the most sensible one to choose but usually ends up making you more depressed for no apparent reason.

Anyway, this carries on for some time. Eventually it just becomes “NEXT”, “PICK OPTION 6 AS IT’S THE ONLY ONE”.

Apparently playing with cats makes you depressed these days. I ended up after trying several times I managed to unlock the therapist and I talked to some guy called Attic who doesn’t actually live in my roof.

I skipped forward because I was starting to get more and more bored by the planck time. Infact the boredom turned into depression it was that lackluster and dull (in a boring way). Anyway, its now Christmas and this is where the game ends.

TL;DR
BORING QUESTIONS, PRETTY LINEAR STORY WITH FEW ACTUAL CHOICES, AND A STORY THAT MADE NO SENSE.

Overall: 1/10. Would NOT recommend.

reviewText:
I've played this a few times few at this point, attempted to compare different endings, but as an interactive fiction/visual novel, the cons outweigh the pros unfortunately.

I appreciate what this game attempts to do for the awareness of depression, but it fails to do so effectively.

At first opening the game, the music tipped me off with the thought, “oh hey, that’s nice. It’s kind of sad. This may help put me in the mood and let me understand what depression is for some.”

I’ve dealt with depression in the past, and no, it’s not fun. It’s tiresome and… depressing (Lol, kind of like this review). But depression is a bit different from one person to another, so knowing how it was like for myself and some other people I’ve been close to, I was curious about how this game would portray it.

First and foremost, the writing is decent. Fortunately for the player, there aren’t any serious flaws that derail the story completely. BUT, there definitely could’ve been more elaboration on the character’s past(s) or relationships with others. There was no real detail about the player’s workplace, or even their boss. Having that relationship explored more could’ve greatly helped the story, even if it was for a short moment.

Halfway through the game, I just stopped caring about the outcome. Which is weird for me, since I’ve trudged through some pretty boring interactive fictions in the past, including those old school text adventures very few people would ever want to play (unless you’re into that sort of thing like me).

Technically, I found this game irritatingly lazy. There’s no save function. I know this seems trivial, but even with the most homebrew of interactive fictions through platforms like Gargoyle or the InfoCom reader, there’s usually a save function. If you find yourself bored wanting to quit to carry on later… YOU CAN’T. You have no other choice but to start from the beginning.

The “branching” story is misleading in the description above. This game is marketed as an interactive fiction with decent options to change the ending, but in reality, there isn’t. Most people aren’t going to play this more than once to realize this, but there is only one ending. Sure a couple words and things may be switched around or replaced, but it’s a lie. Sure your “stats” may be a little better or worse, but it doesn’t change the context of the game greatly enough to be considered truly interactive.

And yes, I understand the crossed out options are options that would be available if you weren’t depressed, but since you’re given so little options, the variance is negligible. Therefore, replay value is at an all-time low. And even though I didn’t want to, I replayed this sucker more than I wanted to. I even went with the worst options available to me, singling me out to depressing options (no pun intended), to see if I would have a super terrible ending… it never came.

From personal experience with depression, I faced myself at the edge of a bridge considering suicide since I’m a terrible swimmer. The choice of suicide never came in this game.

I know this sounds absolutely terrible and I apologize to anybody that may be offended, but when you think the world is better off without you in it, you only drag the people around you down, that God has either forsaken you or isn’t even there, or if you killed yourself the world wouldn’t skip a beat, then yes… suicide, regardless of the stigma, is a viable option to somebody that is depressed, regardless of how terrible of a choice it may be.

An option for this could’ve been suicide, then showing the aftermath of what it would do to the family and friends of the player.

Unfortunately if this choice was made into the game, you never get acquainted well enough with your family and girlfriend enough to actually care. They overall seemed paper thin in character, and sure this detail may be thrown aside as a viewpoint of somebody that's depressed. I get that. But if you want to really grind at the readers views and heart, you need to connect them to the characters and their feelings, including the supporting characters. This may seem pretty basic, but the supporting characters are just as important as the main. And no matter how crappy this sounds, suicide could’ve opened up another heartbreaker end game scenario in the fact that your new kitten would die of starvation because you killed yourself and nobody knew about it for, I dunno... let's throw out some arbitrary numbers: 4-5 days to a week at most.

So yes, I found this game lazy in mechanic and programming. From the lack of options, lack of ending, and lack of a save function. I felt like it always ended with a sigh with no resolution. Which is funny, since the writers at the end of the game thank you for playing stating, “there’s no real end to depression.” Which may be true, but I just found lazy. For a good story, there could still of been a resolution of what happened, even if it’s, “Oh, nothing happened. You stayed depressed and went into a deeper spiral of darkness. Lost your job, and found yourself homeless.” Or, “Your girlfriend Alex, wanting to help you, excorted you to go see a therapist.” Or, “Your family, admitted you to a psyche ward, because they realized your depression got so bad, you weren’t able to function in day to day tasks.” OR, “Your IM friend Attic, realized you didn’t go see the therapist, attempted to get you help in person. You denied. So he called a Suicide help line.” OR, “ANYTHING beyond the same thing, nearly every time.”

The music was okay at first… then it got annoying. And in the end it seemed to actually add to the boredom I found with this game. It definitely didn’t help the more times I played through it. Luckily there’s a mute function in the menu, or you can always just mute your computer audio.

BUT here are the pros…

I appreciate what the game attempts to do.

The pictures getting fuzzier and turning black and white was a nice touch.

The music getting a little distorted the more you get depressed was kind of a nice touch.

I found no typos (unlike this review)

Final verdict:
This game should be Pong and Forgotten.
3.7/10 – Not worth your time unless you’re really curious. OR, you’re a diehard interactive fiction novel gamer and want a taste of everything at some point, despite whether or not you’d like it or not. Which unfortunately for me, I fell under this category.

P.S. I'll probably make a video review of this on my YouTube Channel. I know this is shameless advertising, but idc. It'll probably get me some views and subs because of the whole gamergate crap. Also, It'll knock off anybody thinking that I plagerized my own material since my Youtube name doesn't have the underscore. lol

reviewText:
My main gripe with the game, other than that it shouldn't be on steam to begin with, is that it presents itself in a way that the character just seems sad, not depressed, but it might just be a different form of a depression cycle.

I am someone who was diagnosed with clinical depression, before I started to take medication (Taking mood stabalizers, not anti-depressents, my psychiatrist is a smart dude.) everything didn't seem gloomy and sad like people tend to think of it as, I saw the world exactly the same, the sun shining and the people smiling and ♥♥♥♥ like everyone else does, but I was disconnected from it making me happy because my brain chemistry didn't have the pre-requisites to MAKE me happy.

Maybe people feel depression in a completely different fashion than I do, but the character is written to feel that he should be doing more, he just isn't. For me, I just didn't care, I didn't see a point to, why strive for anything? I often sat outside of the classroom in a ball because first off I couldn't see a ♥♥♥♥ing point in striving to do any of the work, and then furthermore the frustration that you can't do that and you know it's not normal or healthy drives you even further.

It's a continous spiral I feel, and I feel like the character was just in a slump. It doesn't represent my depression, but it might represent less severe cases, so I can't really say NO THIS IS WRONG"
date: but I feel that someone playing this game couldn't learn about how my own depression has affected my life
recommended: and I feel it chips away at the integrity of the game in that instance
hoursPlayed: because it's trying to represent an actual perseption."

reviewText:
only installed and played it now to write a bad review at first, how mature of me.
ive played it before, maybe some months ago, maybe more, and that online, since i heard about it on some imageboards, how its well made and the real deal. wasnt remotely impressed at that point, but gave it some credit for being some gimmicky flash/webgame just like any other.
gave it another shot, maybe they changed something
did not in all that time

sadly it feels plastic and forced, like someone read up on depression in a textbook, watched a documentary and later decided to make a game out of that then. while i can understand that some may experience their depression like its portrayed i highly doubt that it reflects the experience of the majority of people.

game is short as hell, the time displayed, is the time i needed to play it to the end and writing this entire review while it remained opened, and the review took the most time since i suck ♥♥♥ at writing reviews.

a huge flaw was that already after about 4 questions it restricted my freedom of choice to mostly one or just two possible answers, usually the one of the path even further down, which kinda negates the whole decision system doesnt it,

also i had the problem that at some later point of the game none of the possible answers were really pick-worthy or relateable at all, especially when it came to social interaction with loved ones or being a decent human being towards them(alex, internet dude), not involving them in things that they shouldnt have to endure.

i dont know if it comes of as a compliment but this comes close to depression as much as need for speed does to driving.

the consumerbase is there tho, with the aid of all these self-diagnosing snowflakes on tumblr or those corrupt game journalists""

reviewText: Depression Quest for all its stated aims and intentions doesn't quite achieve what it wished to. Although I applaud the intentions of the development team, the execution fails miserably.\n\nWhatever genre/style etc of game you play one of they key focuses is on creating an immersive environment. The first faux pax Depression Quest" commits is to intentionally alienate the player through the constant use of the accusative pronoun "you". Being constantly reminded that you are a player and not the game's protagonist means it is increasingly difficult to actually empathise with Alex. This deliberate alienation between player and game actually detracts from the stated aim which is to "help people understand what it is like to be depressed". The over-use of the pronoun also makes the game appear to be controlling the action and outcomes
date: rather than the player. (Alright that's a highly subjective statement so I will clarify it further). When using accusative pronouns
recommended: we are telling others what we think about them or what to do. As the only interaction the player can engage in is choosing options
hoursPlayed: using the accusative makes the game appear as if it is telling us what to do
voteText: essentially coding a response
helpfulPercent: rather than the player having the illusion of control. This is particularly compounded by the fact that the choices are also phrased in the accusative... i.e. "You choose to stay at home and watch Netflix". Now the styling of "Choose your own adventure" does use the pronoun you
votesHelpful: but usually only when asking the player a question. Questions are a direct
votesTotal: overt engagement that break the narrative (and consequently breaks immersion)
votesFunny: this isn't necessarily the developers fault
commentsCount: it's a fault of the format
column16: but when juxtaposed against the larger narrative it serves to further alienate the player from the story.\nThe sad thing is this could have been easily overcome by simply rewriting the game as a journal
column17: blog or diary and so switching to the pronoun "I". (This is actually a viable option as many counsellors
column18: social workers
column19: psychologists and psychiatrists encourage the keeping of a diary or journal as part of therapy).\nThe writing is tediously unimaginative and dull
column20: and simply fails to hold interest. There is little use of metaphor
column21: simile or any sort of figurative or descriptive language. Now
column22: this may have been a stylistic choice on the part of the writer
column23: Patrick Lindsey

reviewText:
According to this game's prerequisites, I, as well as the vast majority of people that I've ever met are officially depressed. Do you procrastinate? Do you think about past events of your life at night? Ever felt weird at a party where you didn't really know anyone? Have no fear fellow snowflake, there is help available in the form of this empathetic masterpiece.

---

Real talk though, not even criticising it because of the whole backstory. I genuinely downloaded it wanting to like it; wanting  it to be a misunderstood gem which molded eloquence and painful personal experience into a story which communicated the pain of depression (note: the neurological chemical balance, not mere sadness) to a world which doesn't understand it. I wanted this game to thwart the multitude of self-diagnosed sufferers and create a better understanding for the harsh people who've misunderstood the sickness or mistaken it for weakness. What I found instead was material that will serve only to negatively fuel both parties.

It's a relatively small download and free so if there's a level of intrigue regarding the story feel free to pick it up but in terms of being a legitimately worthwhile piece of prose then this ultimately fails.

reviewText:
This visual novel is remarkable in its singular awfulness. The plot centers around someone suffering from a luxurious, hipster style depression that is ill-defined and capable of being treated with a myriad of different options, such as going to a therapist or taking medication. In addition, the main character is even capable of self-sufficiency and has the expendable income to enjoy going to bars. Many people suffering from depression don't have so many options. Often, they're unable to even go to a therapist due to a crippling lack of funding.

However, that's small potatoes compared to the main reason why this game is rubbish:

The writing.

My God, it's like the entire storyline was nuked from orbit by several adverb nuclear missiles. Reading it was like plodding through brambles full of actually's and probably's only to trip over an awkwardly. Repetitive wording and a ruined flow to the sentence structure makes this a certified mess.

What a shame the developers never used a thesaurus.

reviewText:
Oh wow. So, like almost everybody else, I've heard about this thanks to all the controversy surrounding Zoe Quinn and I went into it quite negatively biased. Anyway, I wanted to see what all this fuss was about and I'll try to sum up my thoughts as objectively as I can in this post.


So, with all that out of the way, is Depression Quest a good game? First of all, it's not much of a game. It's done in the classic choose-your-own-adventure style, but it's not done very well. Your choices don't affect the main course of the game very much - they mostly just affect your character's status.

Generally you just get a wall of text and a few options (which options you get depends on your character's status) and you choose one of them. This may cause a change in your character's status, e.g. it can make you more or less depressed. Then you get another wall of text which is a reaction to you choice and then you move on to the next event.

And that's it. Most of the game follows exactly this formula and you shouldn't expect any extensive branching - there isn't any. The only change is right at the very end, and that's simply not enough.

The other problem is that it's quite easy to get a good ending - just pick the choices that make your character actually DO something. And of course it's equally easy to get a bad ending - just pick the choices that make your character do nothing. Usually the choices are even ordered from good to bad, so you really don't need to think about them too much.

Unfortunately all the above means that there is not much replay value. You may go through the game two or three times just to be able to read the different endings, but you really will not be reading all the stuff before that.


Technically the game is alright. Although for some weird reason it has to run in three processes which in total use more than a hundred megs of RAM. I guess it's got something to do with the fact that the game is using Webkit. There's a graphical glitch when the text is shorter than what fits on your screen, but that doesn't cause any problems.


There are a few typographical mistakes, but nothing serious (there will probably be more mistakes in this post than there are in the game :P). I haven't noticed any bad grammar or misspellings.


What is kind of annoying is the sound. Basically, it's just a single repeating piano track which gets boring quite fast. There are some ambient noises for some of the events but nothing major.


And finally we get to the last part. This game obviously deals with depression, which is quite a strong emotional theme. So, did I feel depressed when playing this? Not exactly, although it did show me how a person with depression might feel - or at least I think so.


All in all it's not a great game. The mechanics are weak and the depression part just doesn't do it for me, but that is most likely subjective.

Finally, I do feel that it doesn't deserve all the publicity it's getting, but hey, at least it's free.


tl;dr: I felt more depressed when I couldn't find the bloody keys in Doom.

reviewText:
This is all really,really bad.

First off, I bear no hatred for Zoe Quinn as I don't know much about the situation she's in (something about Five Guys I guess). I am only reviewing her game, Depression Quest...which sucks.

This game is supposed to simulate a depressed person's actions and how they affect those close to him. However, instead of leaving it to the player's imagination about how he feels, the narrator constantly shove emotions down your throat (Ex: You feel depressed. You have nowhere to go"). The characters are dry and one-dimensional. Not much thought was put into them. The music tries to sound sad but in the end it becomes monotonous and annoying to hear after half an hour.

All in all I cannot find a single redeeming factor in "Depression Quest". It is the first novel-type game game I've played

reviewText:
I want to start off by saying I do not have depression and that I have heard a lot of negative things about this game and how it's not really a game etc.

But.
This game, is a game. It does involve choices and a story and somewhat of a level of immersion, now as a game it doesn't really deliver any sort of exposition to the player, it just sort of expects you to pick up on it, which kind of confused me near the beginning, I had questions about who my character was? if it was supposed to be me or someone I'm playing? I also was slightly confused with the cast of characters because of the gender neutral names and the lack of any true back story. So as a game this has a few flaws but the story is not one that's bad, the way its told is not bad, the difficulty is extremely easy but, I don't really see the game as something that is about winning, it seems to be more about experiencing depression through the eyes of this character. I honestly believe this game shouldn't have as much flak as it's getting, I will probably start a discussion to further my opinions on this game because its so.... currently noted.


So now the standard game rating:Story: 7/10 (Its a story and its not really explained well, there are some branching sort of choices but all together its very short but well written.)
Gameplay: X/10 (Text adventure things don't really count for gameplay, all of them have choices and reading, you don't add anything to that normally. Its not bad, but it cannot be rated.)
Presentation: 8/10 (It wasn't just a webpage or something like that, but it wasn't fancy at all either. I like how it mixes everything together well, although that's fairly simple for a game this short.)
Soundtrack: 7/10 (It fits, it ships, but it is annoying as ♥♥♥♥.)
Replayability: 0/10 (Plain and simple I'm not coming back to this game, it was good for one round, maybe two and since its free the replayabilty isn't that much of a factor anyway.)
As a game, it's free, it's not the game that I want to play on a saturday night, nor any other day, for that reason I'm giving it a thumbs down as a GAME. In an informational/emotional way, this game is worth playing if you're curious, or maybe if you have depression.

reviewText:
Depression Quest is an interactive narrative with a set goal: to try to help people who haven’t experienced depression understand what it’s like for the sufferer. However, throughout my time with the narrative, I couldn’t focus as much on the goal of the story because of the poor implementation of the game design itself.

You play as an unnamed character who struggles with depression that progressively gets more burdensome as the game goes on. The goal of using an unnamed character was probably to put the player in the character’s shoes, but for me, it only served to give me no real connection to the character. In the first few pages of the game, when the character is introduced, there are various links to other pages that explain some of the context for future situations. One, for example, is described as “a project you’ve been working on,” but since it doesn’t go into detail, the player loses a connection with the character that could’ve been more personal. At the end of a long section of pages, when the character needs to make a decision, there are a few different options, with the first always crossed out—the next few will continually be crossed out as the depression worsens. This option is clearly supposed to show what the character could do, if not for the depression, but instead it just distracts from the actual possible choices and the player finally picks something to just get past the page.
The music and overall design of each page also leaves the player feeling bored and uninterested.

The supposedly “sad” piano music is distracting from the text, and the page itself, being a static, gray affair, doesn’t do much—if anything—to hold the player’s attention and keep them focused on the story. The status buttons below decision options are also static, with a poor font choice, and slightly distract the player from the options available. Another problem is that you cannot stop playing and pick back up where you left off. For a game with such a bland, boring interface, not having this option makes the player even less likely to want to work back through the game, if they have to stop playing for some reason.

Overall, this game could have been much better, if it had been designed to better keep and hold the player’s attention. As it is, there are too many distracting things going on and not enough draw to the story to keep the player interested and caring about the outcome.

reviewText:
As someone who suffers from depression for over 10 years (and counting, since at least for me, it isn’t something that can be “cured”; sometimes it “goes away”, but it always comes back. It finds its way home and crawls back, even with proper medication/therapy/love/whatever. It’s not that simple, some people might be “cured”, but it’s definitely not the same for everyone else. It’s a constant thing in a person’s life, it appears when you less expect), I felt that this game was not real. First, I felt that the MC was suffering from the effects of depression beginning to grow. But having choices literally locked because apparently “you can’t do that” made me angry. People can TRY to do those things even tho they are depressed! Locking the options was a terrible thing in my opinion, leading the MC to an endless spiral of unworthy feelings, when I actually wanted to help them. This kills the concept of the game, which was supposed to be interactive and you could attempt to make the MC get help.

Character development wasn’t good either. MC was too plain, I couldn’t feel any sympathy for them, same for the other characters. This could have been a decent/good game (I honestly believe that), but it’s not.

Please don’t treat this subject like a superficial aspect. I know this wasn’t meant to be a “happy game”, but it’s not that simple.

reviewText:
The War of 1812 was a military conflict, lasting for two-and-a-half years, fought by the United States of America against the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, its North American colonies, and its American Indian allies. Seen by the United States and Canada as a war in its own right, it is frequently seen in Europe as a theatre of the Napoleonic Wars, as it was caused by issues related to that war (especially the Continental System). The war resolved many issues which remained from the American Revolutionary War but involved no boundary changes. The United States declared war on June 18, 1812 for several reasons, including trade restrictions brought about by the British war with France, the impressment of American merchant sailors into the Royal Navy, British support of Indian tribes against American expansion, outrage over insults to national honor after humiliations on the high seas, and possible American interest in annexing British territory in modern-day Canada.[3]

The war was fought in three principal theatres. Firstly, at sea, warships and privateers of each side attacked the other's merchant ships, while the British blockaded the Atlantic coast of the United States and mounted large raids in the later stages of the war. Secondly, land and naval battles were fought on the American–Canadian frontier, which ran along the Great Lakes, the Saint Lawrence River and the northern end of Lake Champlain. Thirdly, the American South and Gulf Coast also saw big land battles, in which the American forces defeated Britain's Indian allies and a British invasion force at New Orleans. At the end of the war both sides signed the Treaty of Ghent and both parties returned occupied land to its pre-war owner and resumed friendly trade relations.

With the majority of its land and naval forces tied down in Europe fighting the Napoleonic Wars, the British used a defensive strategy in the Provinces of Upper and Lower Canada, repelling initial American invasions. Early victories over poorly led American armies such as the Battle of Queenston Heights, demonstrated that the conquest of the Canadas would prove more difficult than anticipated. Despite this, the Americans were able to inflict serious defeats on Britain's native American allies, ending the prospect of an Indian confederacy and an independent Indian state in the Midwest under British sponsorship. US forces were also able to make several gains on the Canadian frontier; taking control of Lake Erie in 1813 and seizing western parts of Upper Canada. However a large-scale American attempt to capture Montreal was repulsed in November 1813, and serious American attempts to conquer Upper Canada were ultimately abandoned following the bloody Battle of Lundy's Lane in July 1814.

In April 1814, with the defeat of Napoleon, the British adopted a more aggressive strategy, sending larger invasion armies and tightening their naval blockade. However, with the end of the Napoleonic Wars in Europe, both governments were eager for a return to normality and peace negotiations began in Ghent in August 1814. In September 1814, the British invaded and occupied eastern Maine. In the south-west, General Andrew Jackson destroyed the military strength of the Creek nation at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend. The British victory at the Battle of Bladensburg in August 1814 allowed them to capture and burn Washington, D.C, but they were repulsed in an attempt to take Baltimore. American victories in September 1814 at the Battle of Plattsburgh repulsed the British invasions of New York, which along with pressure from merchants on the British government prompted British diplomats to drop their demands at Ghent for an independent native buffer state and territorial claims that London previously sought. Both sides agreed to a peace that restored the situation before the war began. However, it took six weeks for ships to cross the Atlantic so news of the peace treaty did not arrive before the British suffered a major defeat at New Orleans in January 1815.[4]

In the United States, late victories over invading British armies at the battles of Plattsburg, Baltimore (inspiring their national anthem, The Star-Spangled Banner") and New Orleans produced a sense of euphoria over a "second war of independence" against Britain.[5][6] The Federalist Party had strongly opposed the war effort and prevented New England from providing much in the way of soldiers and troops; it now virtually collapsed. The war ended on a high note for Americans

reviewText:
As a person who suffers from depression and has to deal with the hardships on a day to day basis I can honestly say that I am offended that this title is trying to say that it recreates such difficulties in any way. The writing barely skims over daily challenges, makes it seem like therapy and medication are miracle cures, and that depression is just easily overcome. Yes, at the end of the story it says some fluff about this being a lifelong struggle, but the story never delvs into anything more than superficially. It feels as though the warnings of possible triggers were only put in place so that persons who actually suffer from this condition don't see this and point out how absolutely flawed it is.

Putting the subject matter aside, I am offended that this somehow managed to get through Steam's Greenlight program when so many great games do not. This is arguably a game, and it fails on all accounts even when it comes to interactive fiction. The audio is abysmal, coming across as annoying more than saddening, what little graphics are present are blurry and come across more as product placements, and the interactivity is so minute that I felt the need to write this review to get the value from my time spent.

Depression Quest should be avoided, removed from Steam, and the developers should be scolded for ever releasing it.

reviewText:
I heard about this game from all of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that last few days revolving around its creator.  I was diagnosed with severe depression in high school and went though several anti-depressants and therapists. I'm now in my last semester of college and all is going well but High School was rough on me but mostly on my family.  So, I was thinking that I could possibly be able to relate to this game because of my past experiences.  I could not, this is not a good representation of depression and it is not a good representation of video games, hell it isn't even a game.

Ok, so what is the game?  It is a text based adventure where you are given a set of text and then have to choose a reponse based on that.  These response are in the form of hypertext and this could basically be a webpage and there would be no difference.  Whatever, the actualy gameplay is bland but it is text based, what would you expect?

My core issue here lies in the representation of depression and the way the adventure" is set up.  So it starts you as a depressed person with not much context as to how you got there.  Then
date: it throws you in with a cast of characters who seem  to want to help you but no matter what I did my character was constantly in a downward spiral.  It seemed like the creator was under the impression that a depressed person can only be helped by therapy and SSRI's (anti-depressants).  This game perpuates the idea (which is wrong) that all depression can be fixed with drugs and that all depression is basically the same.  This is anything but though truth
recommended: there are thousands of factors that can influence depression.  Diet

It is a terrible representation of depression because depression is something that simply can't be represented in a video game.\n\nThere are reasons that doctors spent years and years studying depression and mental illnesses because there are millions of factors and millions of solution and possiblities.  This game is not just an embarrassment to video games but to people who are unlucky enough to suffer from depression and or anxiety.  How this game got past greenlight simply blows my mind.  I can not recommend this game at all

reviewText:
While the creators have the sense to acknowledge that all depressions are different, this does not sound like depression. The biggest problem this game has is completely preventing you from doing the 'best' choices.
Depression is not like that.
If you are depressed, doing the 'best' thing is hard, but not impossible.
If the options were running, the 'best' option would be running twice as far as any other option.
Harder, requiring more effort, not impossible. They do, however, often feel impossible.
This game tries to represent depression, and to does so poorly. This game shows what a person who has never had depression, but has done some background research on it, would think depression is like. The reviews left on the main site feel forced, because the reviewers may have feared being accused of misogyny, and do not accurately reflect the actual game. But I digress.

This game portrays depression as nearly a hopeless spiral of constant self loathing and negativity. Which never leaves your mind naturally.
That isn't what depression is like, it implies that depressed people cannot be happy at all.
It couldn't be more wrong

reviewText:
Despite the controversy surrounding this game, I was very interested in trying it out.

As someone who has had (maybe even still dealing with) depression, I was excited to see its entry into the gaming world.

Unfortunately, I found I was troubled by the image of depression that this game offers, and I have to wonder if this could do more harm than good.

It didn't feel as if the person the player is controlling is even a person. I felt like I was wheeling a wooden plank through a series of rooms, so lacking in personality or any distinguishable features that I found myself bored, and struggling to read the text that was telling me how I was 'feeling'. It worries me that the person this game is portraying is dull, boring, robotic. While some ambiguity and vagueness is needed in order for any player to put themselves in the character's shoes, I felt like that vagueness was taken to a point where we can no longer truly care for the character.

I was also troubled by the lack of options. As someone who has experienced depression, I know that there are times where it feels like options are limited. But people don't express depression in the same way. I have been the person that, despite feeling like death inside, I went out, feigned happiness. I went out and did things, even if I wasn't being honest with people, and that was part of my problem. That was something I had to deal with for years, giving the appearance I was happy and healthy, when I wasn't. I was disappointed to find that so many of the options I'd have chosen, the options that would make sense to not just me, but probably many other people just trying to survive, and maintain the life one has, were just simply crossed out, as if the mere thought of doing such a thing was preposterous.

I couldn't help but feel just a bit insulted by that. That my experience was an impossibility.

So no, I would not recommend this game. Not to my friends, not to people who have never experienced depression,

and most definitely not to others who have gone through what this game tries desperately to depict.

DO NOT TOUCH THIS GAME.

If you relate to any of the above, please note that Depression Quest is little more than a huge pile of depression triggers.

I gave this game two chances. I first checked out the website and then the game here on Steam. I spent over two hours going through different options.

The writing itself is mediocre. The decisions you make from one encounter to the next have some impact on what happens next, but not a whole lot, other than determining if the protagonist gets more or less depressed. The more depressed, the less likely the character will be able to dig himself out, reach out to friends or otherwise seek help.

For a resource focused primarily on text, it sure has a LOT of typos.

If you are someone interested in reading the diary of a depressed person, Depression Quest may be for you. If you are having trouble communicating with a depressed loved one, perhaps this can be useful to gain some insight into your loved one's mind.

However, do not bother installing this through Steam. Just look up the web site. They're EXACTLY THE SAME.

reviewText: Although the game creates a frame through which the player can easily see the impact depression has on its protagonist, I found the delivery to be dull and its theme too pushy. reviewText: Depression Quest has stirred up quite the controversy and has already received many negative reviews as well as a lot of troll reviews that are to be honest hilarilously funny. I was really tempted to write a troll review myself but I'll try to give a honest review here. Im aware that it is highly debatable if Depression Quest qualifies as a game or not but I will at times refer to it as the game" and to the act of using it as "playing". I don't want to scratch the topic if it's a game or not but I'll use those words for convenience.\n\nIn Depression Quest you play as a person with depression trying to manage daily life. The game is fairly minimalistic and basically looks like a website with white background and some gifs. It can be controlled with the mouse or suprisingly with a gamepad. Depression Quest plays like a "choose your own adventure"-book. You basically read a short story and sometimes get to choose from a set of options to determine how the story continues. The problem is that despite the advertising there is not much to choose from here. Some people complain that many of the options are crossed out and not selectable. However
date: I think that is actually getting the point of knowing what the right thing to do is while being unable to do it across. Depression Quest portrays depression and it does not do a particularly bad job at it but it is all that it does. It does not offer any way out
recommended: what is depressing in itself. If that was the point of it then it works out well but I think that there should be more to it. As it stands Depression Quest does work as an art project but has severe shortcomings in the game department. The writing is not great but is does its job. It just feels too clichéd at times. During the first minute it almost put me off immediately though because it comes with a trigger warning. Also it describes the protagonist as a "human being" instead of specifying the gender or just using ''you''. The problem is that the developer apparently forgot about that part immediately. For the rest of the game it is clear that the player character is in fact male. I really wonder what the original point was then.\n\nI would not recommend Depression Quest to anybody who is actually suffering from depression or anybody not interested in the topic. If you want to get a basic understanding of the way people with depression think it's worth a look though. However
hoursPlayed: I say that only because it is free. If it would cost actual money I would advise you to stay away from it.\n\nDepression Quest is not completely horrible but below average and has next to no target audience. To a certain degree it does what it was set out to do. What it does is however not for everyone
voteText: even among the expected target audience. Some people with living depression may share similar experiences to those depicted in the game
helpfulPercent: others won't at all. If you want to play a simplistic game that explores the human condition you are better off with Papers
votesHelpful: Please since that game does not simply describe a situation but presents you with a moral dilemma and communicates its message through actual gameplay. As for Depression Quest... it takes no advantage of the medium at all.\n\nMore reviews here"

reviewText:
I would not recommend this game for a variety of reasons:

1) The game is very uninteresting. Each page, if you wanna call it that, is literally a long story. I'd have no problem with this if this were a book or some other medium, but there really is no gameplay, something that could potentially really connect you with the feeling the game is trying to show.

2) The game seems to show a rather extreme side of depression where everything is doom and gloom. I won't contest this as being a real life possibility, but it would seem that a greater impact could be given if there was a build up, a slow, gripping build up that led to the intial level of depression seen in the game. Then maybe it could show how bad and dangerous depression can really get if left untreated.

3) The person behind this game, Zoe Quinn, is a total hack in the industry. Based on evidence compiled around the internet by actual legitimate sources, she has done nothing but produce sympathy toward herself through falsehoods and fake outrage. Tack on to this the fact that she somehow has several journalists and indie developers in her pocket, presumably because of the fact she has dated them and then used this to her advantage by getting positive coverage of her out and then destroying any negative coverage, be it legitimate or not, just goes to show how corrupt ♥♥♥♥ can get.

I do not recommend this game. If it were remade with some better design choices, it may be a great way to show the effects of depression to others and help people who have depression. But with its current state, and the fact that it really only exists to further Zoe Quinn's agenda, it is a sure pass.

reviewText:
Before I begin, I've noticed that due to recent controversy, this game has received a large amount of backlash, all of which is either a personal attack on the people behind it or dismissing it, based on the first screen. I hope to be a little more constructive...

I was quite looking forward to Depression Quest as I'm no stranger to depression, I've felt different kinds in the past and I'm currently going through a rough patch at the moment. I was also a big fan of Dear Esther, another game that centered around depression, loss and grief and I loved To the Moon for its similar themes.

I was equally as disappointed as most to see that the game was about advanced as a basic website, a white background, with text and a depressing piano rift but, obviously, I tried to see past that and tried to judge the game on its story and the things that it DOES offer.

What it offers is a scenario, in which it tells you, your problem and then gives you a list of options, asking you how you would proceed. I usually like this style of storytelling, like in Tell Tale's games or your average RPG and went along with it but I was a bit puzzled to see that two of the options were crossed out and one of them was the option that I would have picked. It didn't take me long to see through the message, that this game appeared to be conveying.

The logical answer is always crossed off the list, meaning that people suffering from depression aren't capable of ever doing the logical thing. Though this may be true for some cases, it's not true for EVERYONE and it's certainly isn't a rock hard fact. The reason that it, especially, bothers me is the fact that the only thing you do is read a wall of text before making a decision and after a few minutes, the decision aspect is completely taken away from you, to the point that you just read a wall of text and then click the only option presented to you.

I tried to make it to the end, hearing that it tries to accurately simulate depression, by taking the colour out of the world but I just couldn't get to the end of it. I was incredibly bored and I couldn't even get worked up over it anymore, the music was just depressing the hell out of me and I found myself trapped in a seemingly endless monotonous cycle, where I just read text and clicked options, that weren't mine.

I've always been very liberal with my definition of what a game is, some said that Dear Esther wasn't a game and I argued against that but this? I don't know, I don't believe that it is a 'game' as you could recreate the experience by listening to a playlist of every depressing song/theme you know, whilst reading something off of fanfiction.net and occasionally slapping yourself across the face.

In conclusion; I wouldn't recommend it, I don't believe that it is an accurate portrayal of depression and I struggle to see where the 'it's a game!' argument is coming from.

If you want a better experience, I'd recommend Dear Esther or To the Moon over this as both are much better interractive stories.

reviewText:
Terrible. Just a terrible mess of a game.
Where do I even begin? From a gameplay standpoint, it's boring. There's nothing visually stimulating (and while I realize that's not the point with choose your own adventure games-but something semi-decent would have been nice, a background to simulate scene changes), and it's all too easy to get the good ending if you have even a sliver of an idea how choose your own adventure games work. The story is bland at best and does nothing to suck the player in and make them care about the character their playing as. Honestly, 3/4 of the way through and I found myself skimming the mammoth-sized paragraphs of crap just to get to my options. Speaking of options, why cross out the ones that would actually help you? I'm speaking from an odd position here, as I have never been diagnosed with depression, but it feels strange that, in an attemtpt to simulate someone being depressed you wouldn't present the helpful option as an option. To the people who played this game who actually have depression, did that feel condescending at all? Plus, the character is completely self-absorbed. There's a point in the game where one of your friends is having some nasty issues in their life and instead of consoling them, you can choose to just ignore him because you feel that you have it worse. Even though this person is a life-long friend you can still opt to turn your back on them. And a trigger warning? Really?

Would not recommend this game if you're looking for something good to play. Would recommend this game if you want to have another reason to dislike Zoe Quinn.

reviewText: Didn't like it. I may be being a little harsh as I know this is a hard topic, and I know it's trying to portray depression which can be a very individual thing, but disliked the way there were right and wrong choices. Don't want to go talk to a doctor?...well that means you can't go talk to your friends or family instead 'cos we're going to grey it out. I mean there's no way you could help yourself....you need MEDICATION! (Or that's the impression I got from this game anyway.) Yeah I get it, it's meant to be a spiral, but I don't think it's the greatest representation even from an individual standpoint. It's more like someone's idea of what they think depression should be like, but comes off more like someone who's just whiny and can't help themselves without managing to incite any understanding or compassion at all. Can think of many better resources for people wanting to read up more on what depression is.\n\nIt's also concerning the play though I did at least, makes out like there is no end to it and you'll be miserable your entire life which I think is very misrepresented and a dangerous message, especially for those with current clinical depression. My opinion- skip it.

reviewText: Being diagnosed with depression, I'd say that there may have been a better way of depicting it than with just words.  Use more visuals, lights, show how fast your thoughts go by..  And anyone who is not being treated for depression may be discouraged by the ending.  It was a bit boring, since there wasn't a lot of player interaction, it was mostly just reading a book. Depression does get better, it never completely leaves you, yes, but it doesn't leave you in feeling only halfway okay.  You have good days.  Also: there should be two stories, so you can chose your gender or even insert your name, to make it feel more personal.

reviewText:
This game seems to be confusing depression with boredom or lazyness because that's honestly all I felt while playing with options basically breaking down between Do Something (Which you can't do) or Do Nothing.

It also didn't help that there were constant reminders of how I was feeling depressed and could do nothing about it.

Honestly that's all I really have to say about it because there's not much else. I understand it's coming from the point of view of someone else suffering from depression, but honestly I think that person is just... lazy.

Source: I've dealt with depression throughout my entire life and it's never convinced me to not go to work, not get paid and just stay in bed all day. It's actually a part of my personality that I complement with intense cynicism and sarcasm -- which essentially makes me one of the most negative people imaginable -- yet I still manage to go throughout my daily routine. I just suffer all the while in silence, like most people I know with depression.
