reviewText: I'll preface this review by saying that it's highly unlikely that anybody is checking out Depression Quest in total ignorance of the massive storm of internet drama surrounding it, and I'm no exception. Thus, my view of this piece of interactive (non)fiction" isn't the product of going in completely blind.\n\nI don't have any problems with visual novels
hoursPlayed: since they can be great experiences if executed well (insert plug for The Stanley Parable here). However
voteText: Depression Quest has some major issues that ultimately cause it to fall flat. The writing is poor on a technical level: it's difficult to get immersed in a text-heavy experience when you have to wrestle with typos
helpfulPercent: ambiguous pronoun references
votesHelpful: and unnecessary alliteration. In addition
votesTotal: instead of being written in a way that evokes certain emotions in the reader
votesFunny: Depression Quest explicitly tells you how you feel every step of the way. This caused me to approach the experience in a disconnected
commentsCount: analytical manner. Finally
column16: perhaps due to my disconnect with the "player character
column17: it was far too simple to determine the proper series of choices to guide the character toward a solution to their depression (protip: don't lay in bed all week).\n\nIn conclusion, although I personally can't speak to whether or not Depression Quest is an accurate representation of chronic depression, I couldn't force myself to care about the events in the story due to awkward, weak execution. But hey, if you don't believe me, it's free and only takes about half an hour to go through once, so it's not too hard to form your own opinion.

reviewText: I've struggled with depression for the last 4 years and this game was a joke to me. It's the typical 'no one loves me/I'm a burden' stuff and it's basic. There was nothing to draw me into the story and the best part of the game was probably the picture of the cat. This felt more like a chore and not a form of 'entertainment' (for lack of better words). It was boring, plain, and a waste of time. The choices you make have very little effect on the aactual game as the game will have the same outcome, and that is no real outcome. Either you do good and get over it or you do bad and you dont. If this game is trying to show someone how it feels to be depressed, it's failing horribly. Making decisions isn't as easy as clicking a button. You cant show someone how it is to be depressed through a video game. If you want to try and see what it's like for someone who's going through a depression and struggling, go play The Cat Lady.\nOverall, this game was a disappointment and could possibly be one of the worst games I've played in my entire 18 years.\n

reviewText:
Criteria - Score out of 5
Controls - 1
Design - 1
Playability/Gameplay	 - 1
Entertainment level (How quickly did you lose interest?) - 1
Technical flaws (bugs, glitches, etc.) - 2
Cost - 5
Identity - (Idea behind game, Is it unique?) - 5
Graphics - 1
Artifical Intelligence Competency - 1
Storyline - 2
Writing Technicalities - 1
Voice Acting - 1
Music (Does it have soundtracks? Is it enticing to the mood?) - 1
Genre Structure - 1
Return Factor - 1
Average Score - 2

As everyone knows, a game is entitled a fair chance. 'Depression Quest' is unique in its development as it brings forward the viewpoints and emotional curtains that define depression. However, it is only applicable to one scenario. It in fact plays through the possible actions of a single person in a very specific environment. The limited actions allow for smooth transitioning, but are generally lacking for what gamers consider to be a developing title.

With all else said and done, the game was fairly straight-forward in its guided direction. Did you fight through the depression, or did you succumb to what would be a vision-altering take on an individuals inner turmoil. With multiple paths to choose from which gradually became more and more limited as time progressed, one could feel restricted to their options, an argument which invalidates the free-thought that many gamers wish to experience. With no real graphical rendering save for a very contrasting back-drop to the text, I found my eyes hurting and straining, consistently reminding myself that this game looked more like a website than an actual game. There wasn't any Artificial Intelligence to interact with so the choices seemed rather stale in comparison to other titles. As for the images that did perceive themselves, the images were repetative and didn't give an ebb or flow to the text, so when it came up with changes in time, it felt much like a car slamming into a concrete baricade, and other times it felt like time was at a stand-still.

The music was a single repetitive track that played itself over and over again and was almost maddening in and of itself, so the feel was genuinely successful, but the music felt out of place at many points in the story line. As a fast reader, I was able to play through this game in roughly twenty minutes with all possible endings. On that note, the gameplay was very short, and the replay factor was damaged by my own personal abilities. That being said, it felt short and fairly lacking in immersive content. Credit shall be given, however, into the emotions that the game drew out. Having suffered from depression myself, a majority of the situations actually forced myself to review my own experiences in some self-reflection and as I am writing this, I can't help but feel emotionally connected to the game. However, I must remain clinical and give an honest review, and so my personal feelings will be directed in a more professional manner.

The last questions that come to mind are fairly straight-forward. Is this a game, and does it befit the genre advertised? The answer to these questions is an undeniable, No." Depression Quest feels more like a book that you would select your choice

reviewText:
The game tries to deliver an okayish story with much pathos, but it really just doesn't accurately portray a clinical depression.
The description of the issues the main character is having are as vague as it gets. The game simply boils it down to 3 symptoms. Being anxious, antisocial and having a bad mood. This sadly doesn't do much justice to the complexity of the illness at all. It also doesn't count in any of the problems that come with it, like forgetfulness, irrational input evaluation and the side effects of medication.
It seems like the game is about someone who is having a hard time being depressed, rather than suffering from a major depressive disorder.

tldr; Not in-depth, but okay story. Still would not recommend to anyone interested in this particular topic. Go, read a book about it. Much more worth your time.

reviewText:
This is a game? Hahaha, oh wow

In all seriousness it's a interactive story about some random guy and his depression and you have to direct his actions via multiple choice outcomes. You could probably speed play through it in 1 minute; there's not that much of a story to it. It's not really that much of a game. Maybe it could've been considered one back in the 80s or 90s when they had those interactive text based ones, but even those usually were a lot longer than this and more interesting as well.

Now I don't like to use Ad hominems but the broad who made this, Zoe Qunin, didn't even make it directly. She got help from some game makers who were doing a project where they'd help inexperienced women make games. After they helped her make this, she attacked them! Also, after Robin Williams took his life (rest in piece, you were one of the few celebrities I actually felt horrible from after they died) she tried to cash in on that to promote her game more. So she also has no respect for victims of suicide. There's been a massive storm of controversy over her actions, and a lot of censoring of facts and freedom of speech. So I encourage you, the audience, not to support her.

Depression is a hellish sickness of the mind that nobody should experience. I can appreciate trying to find ways to make people understand it much better, but this 'game' is an inefficient way off doing so, and it's creator is shrouded in controversy.

I cannot recommend this game. Thankfully, it is free, so I didn't waste a dime.

reviewText:
To get it out of the way immediately, I have Bi-polar depression.
This 'game' is not an accurate depiction of depression in the least. It is a depiction of someone who is depressed. There is in fact a difference here.
Much of the text trivializes the long term issues and makes it appear as if this is something the character is just now dealing with, as in it suddenly appeared. While it is possible for someone with untreated clinical depression to have a girlfriend, a job, a (apparent) group of friends, and overall live a normal life, that is near miraculous as depicted in this game. I attempted to self-manage my depression for years without help, and can tell you that social withdrawal and self-esteem issues are pretty much a given in this kind of situation.
I truly think this 'game' utterly fails to depict the mental state of someone with clinical depression. There are a number of issues with the presentation, even aside from the inexplicably understanding people surrounding the character, such as the portrayal of anti-social behavior as a direct result of depression. Some people genuinely don't like other people, and have issues connecting with them, thus seeing avoidance as a way to not have to deal with the added stress trying to deal with that you don't understand creates. I know I'm anti-social. I also know that my being anti-social has nothing to do with my depression, but more to do with just not having the desire for social interaction. That is the root cause of anti-social behavior in most people. Social withdrawal is getting so anti-social that it begins to affect your life negatively.
Moving on from that, I cannot call this an accurate portrayal of even caricaturized depression. It portrays someone who is depressed, and fails to do that very well, due to a number of misconceptions on the creator's part on what depression is, and on what the effects are.

reviewText:
Just finished the game. Despite the short amount of time it took to complete, it felt like an eternity.

I wanted to give it a fair chance, but there was no game here. The design of the game is just lazy. It's so bland and uninteresting to look at that I really couldn't focus on the story. It's white background, with black text, and a picture on top that pertains to the story.

Whenever I could actually look at what was going on, I was extremely disappointed in the lack of originality of the situation I was in. The story is that I have a girlfriend and family who all love me and are concerned about my depression. WHOOP-DEE-DOO!!! I got excited when someone gave me a kitten. I thought that would make it a good game, but the cat POSSIBLY only shows up one other time. There was no connection with any of the characters really since they're all nothing more than cliches.

The game has a total of ONE TRACK of a short piano piece on a loop. There will be background noises sometimes depending on the area which can make this short track even more annoying than it actually is. I would go insane listening to it as I merely got the gist of what was going on. I can't imagine what would happen if I took the time to go over all the details.

The whole thing about this game is making choices. It doesn't matter how many choices the GAME says there are because in reality there are only two every time. There can be 6 choices the GAME gives you, but there are really only two. It lists some options only to cross them out because you're TOO DEPRESSED" which is just the most infuriating thing a game about choices can do. I understand my character is depressed
date: but don't tell me you're restricting my options because of this. Depression doesn't mean incapable of choosing to do enjoyable things. Depression doesn't make some options impossible
recommended: but it does make some options more difficult to make because of the emotional weight that just doesn't seem like something to bring around other people. The choices that were presented in this game seemed like they were made to guide the player towards one over the others. I can't choose the crossed out option
hoursPlayed: but I can choose the option that's the crossed out option with different words. The obvious right option sometimes is actually not always the obvious right option for someone who isn't depressed. The writers basically assume that this is how a normal life should be and anyone who isn't living like this is depressed. I don't have time for parties
voteText: internet interaction
helpfulPercent: and Netflix with a girlfriend when MY JOB is on the line. Depression should have nothing to do with that. Do my choices really matter? Only when it comes down to choosing to see a therapist and taking medicine is when it truly matters. The game is always telling you that you're not doing those things
votesHelpful: so obviously the player can deduce that those are the things that must be done in order to win the game. In the real world a therapist and medication does NOT fix all cases of depression. Sometimes these things cause people to become more lost and more depressed.\n\nI do not believe that this game depicts depression exactly. There are many ways people can struggle with depression and I've only seen one very generic and uneducated depiction in Depression Quest. The writing is made to make your character obviously sad when sometimes it's not always so obvious even to those affected by this terrible state of mind. I
votesTotal: along with some of the other reviewers here

The game gives a trigger warning to anyone who has been depressed that this game might be too real and may emulate our own lives too well. IT DOES NOT!!! reviewText:
First of all, this is not a game, it is an interactive story which only really goes in one direction even though you seemingly pick different ways to go about the story, you end up with the same results really.

Secondly, this game does not do what it's meant to, which is educate people on the real struggles of depression. All this story does is tell the reader about the authors point of view on depression from what seems to be from a female mindset, which is not educating people correctly on the matter.

This story doesn't express the difficulty of actually dealing with depression and how frustrated and hopeless you actually feel when dealing with this illness and even though the charactor refers to being 'exhausted' and 'emotionally drained', this is not the whole of what people feel in their battle with depression. This so called game is wrongly educating people on the subject.
Also, if you're struggling with depression this 'game' is not for you, as all it does is make you feel worse about yourself and the direction in which your own life is going, so don't waste your time on this poor excuse of a game.

Overall, the music is terrible and repetative, the story is inacurate about the struggles of depression and it is wrongly categorised (this is most certainly not an RPG).
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay so real talk from someone who has had clinical Depression since they were 9.

Depression sucks. Big time. A lot of the thought processes, situations, and dialogue that are used in this 'game' are somewhat relatable to some of my own experiences. The not feeling good enough for your partner, being emotionally exhausted, having to pep yourself up for menial activities...It's a lot more difficult than people realize, and I will give some credit to Depression Quest for trying to shed some light on that, for the small hints of it that are there.

However, while I understand what this was trying to accomplish, there are better ways of doing so. This is not a game. It is an interactive journal essentially. It is trying to be a new-age look into a 'deep' soul that ends up sounding very pretentious. I just know most people do not want to sit and read walls of text(s) of sad things, which is probably one of the major reasons Depression Quest has been so negatively received. There's also the fact that the story overall really isn't even that engaging. I started skipping over entries after the seventh one and just clicked the most positive options to get to the end. I also can't stand the title. As another reviewer stated, Depression is not a 'quest' where you get a nice little reward for making it to the end. It's draining and exhausting. It's learning how to cope and when you think everything is fine and figured out, the rules change again for no reason. Basically, it's not nearly as straight-forward as this 'groundbreaking game' claims to be.

I read a bit on Zoe Quinn and her desire to create a more straight-forward game because all the ones dealing with Depression are more metaphorical and about symbolism (which I prefer personally). Well, congratulations Zoe. You created your snorefe-masterpiece!

reviewText: The game was boring. There was nothing to hook me and make me say, “I want to keep playing” I was mostly saying, “when is this going to end”. I usually like to go back and try different choice but I wouldn’t in this game because it was so dull. The writing in the game was very mundane I often had to read it a second time because I had drifted off. The choices also felt very fake and were not really choices because a lot of the time they were almost forced upon you.  The choices also made it seem like the devs did not want you to come out of your depression. The game also felt like it rushed the story. The story takes place over months but the writing makes it feel like it took place over a week. That is what overall made the game feel fake to me I didn’t feel like the protagonist I felt like a person clicking buttons and making choices that didn’t really affect me. I wouldn’t recommend this game to anyone and I wouldn’t play it again maybe if the devs did a major rework on it like change the writing and made it seem real but that’s a soft maybe.

reviewText:
I went into this with an open mind, despite the sad tactics of the developer to rally troops into getting this greenlit. Twice. Upon playing it, I noticed a few things. This is, a graphical choose your own adventure book. But, I feel it sadly lacks substance. It doesn't touch on real depression. It doesn't at all represent those of us who have dealt with it. Struggled with it.

The narrative feels hollow at times. Disjointed. Even by graphic novel standards, this seems to be a hodgepodge of poorly done tripe. But the worst of it is, this simply doesn't touch on the real darkness of depression. The self apathy. The grueling feelings of despair. Perhpas another medium other than point and click might have worked. Random events, for example. A different format or engine.

As it is, I found this game lacking in every way. I found no emotional connection to a game that wants me to feel connected to it. To relate to it. I find it does a horrid job even depicting depression itself. It's simply a series of cliking on choice, and get better or worse. That's not even one tenth accurate. It's not showing the troubles one faces in feeling down, then depressed, then the utter despair.

I tried going into this with an open mind, and realized this game was simply awful.
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: As a person who has suffered with depression for the majority of his life, and a person who loves visual novels like Ace Attorney and Professor Layton. I can't bring it to myself to give this game a good review. I tried to give this game at least one full playthrough but after about 10 minutes I really couldn't do it. I understand what this game is trying to do but honestly its execution is downright ♥♥♥♥ poor. I know everyones battle with depression is different and many people deal with it in different ways but this game only gives, in my opinion, a sterotypical depression outlook. Some of the good options to pick through to advance in the story are crossed off. As it seems like a person battling with depression is unable to do those things. It would have done the game more justice to let the player pick some of the more social and common things to see how a person with depression would react to them! I know when I was battling with depression I still tried my hardest to do what was right and I went after help to get things under control. So overall do yourself a favor and don't play this game. The game isn't even worth it to be free. Go download the demo for Five Night's at Freddys or something. Or if you want a good visual novel expierence go pick up Professor Layton vs. Phoenix Wright:Ace Attorney next week.\n\nI'll probably sit down and play the game from start to finish and give my full thoughts on this, however the game just isn't worth your time.

reviewText:
Here's a CYOA where you're a depressed dude. It isn't very engaging, it isn't a game and I don't understand why it's on Steam. Bullet points go!

1) It fails to illustrate depression because of the faux-game format; the whole tragedy of it in real life is that you don't know it'll ever end, whereas this obviously has a happy ending.

2) The protagonist has a fantastic life and everyone bends over backwards to support him, so it's kinda hard to sympathize.

3) The music gets very grating.

4) It's a CYOA with no game elements at all, did I mention this?

reviewText:
If this define the future of gaming then I will be depressed... not only depressed... SUICIDAL! Don't get me wrong, I like reading! I've been playing the latest interactive novel released on Android such as House of Hell, Blood of the Living Dead and Lone Wolf. And I've been collecting Fighting Fantasy gamebooks for age!

But this...
This...
Has nothing to do with what I grew up with.

The title Depression Quest" is very misleading. I thought the game would be about reaching the deepest level of depression. What a fool I was!

So basically
date: you play some boy who as a hard time being positive and living an enjoyable day. The story is set in a very generic context: you live with your mother
recommended: you have an old brother and a girlfriend
hoursPlayed:
you have a job and everything seems to fall apart. The writing style doesn't manage to deliver the complexities of depression. It is like listening to a casual conversation so there is nothing creative about the writing. The writer has absolutely no imagination.

The music is alright but it is the same throughout the whole playthrough.
The game uses some images to help the "reader" to get an idea of what is going on but there are too few of them.
The mission goal is to meet a therapist and take medication so you can feel better. What kind of institutional propaganda is that?!

Even if the game is free
voteText:
it's still a ripoff. The game doesn't deserve that much attention.
♥♥♥♥ing a video game journalist will not save the game from bad reviews.
A bad game is a bad game.

I hate to say it but...
I can list a number of bad games that are better than Depression Quest: The Graveyard (dare I say it!)

reviewText:
There are two things I want to discuss here.  The game itself, and the controversy.

The Game:

This is not a traditional game, rather a kind of interactive novel.  It is more along the lines of a choose-your-own-adventure type game.

It follows the life of someone struggling with depression, in the second person, in an attempt to illustrate the experience.

While it's a noble goal, the game itself tries to beat the atmosphere and helplessness into you in such an awkward way that playing this is unpleasant.  Not in an uncomfortable because it's thought-provoking" way
date: but an "I can't do anything" way.\n\nWere it not for the disclaimer page before the game starts
recommended: I would be concerned about it trivializing the condition by stereotyping it.\n\nI have not put much time into this game
hoursPlayed: and I don't think I will.  It's just too uncomfortable.  Fortunately if you do try it
voteText:
it is not very long and can be finished in a matter of minutes.

The Controversy:

Face it.  The negative reviews and forum posts on this game are not because of the game itself
helpfulPercent: but are about the creator
votesHelpful: Zoe Quinn.  Quinn's ex-boyfriend made a number of allegations about her
votesTotal: and her personal life basically went viral.  It's become a sport in the last few weeks to attack Quinn directly and indirectly for the unforgiveable sin of "doing it".  It's like the Internet is made of middle school kids giggling while getting their shamesticks out.\n\nLook.  We get it.  She isn't a nun
votesFunny: nor did she claim to be.  That has nothing to do with the game.  Even when you try to disguise misogyny as being about journalistic integrity
commentsCount: or honesty
column16: or whatever excuse gets used.  When the method is calling someone a "hooker" or making "5 guys" jokes
column17:
that's not about journalism.  That's about her private life.

Conclusion:

This game is not fun or enjoyable.  It's kind of an interesting experiment
column18: but most people will probably want to avoid it.  Unfortunately a straight review is hard to find in the nest of cruel and inappropriate snark.  This game is marred by the public reaction to it."

reviewText:
When I finished Depression Quest, I was taken on a journey of discovery as I tailed the story of a man who has suffered Depression. It's a wonderful game with lots of potential and is crisply written and nocely noted.

Now what I say beyond this point is basically a spoiler and if you intend on playing the game, I don't recommend reading. But if your interested on why I don't recommend it, keep reading.

As a man who's had major depression, and has been diagnosed with Schizoaffective Disorder (A disease that makes it harder to comprehend reality and gives you immense mood swings.), I have to say that the justification given in the ending I GOT, is NOT the way to approach depression. It doesn't matter if the story has multiple branches and has various amounts of endings, it should all end in the RIGHT way to treat depression and not with the going excuse of just saying deal with it".

For one thing
date: depression is not something you can just accept and just let it pass. Like any form of mental disorder
recommended: it can be treated with the right amount of medicine and seeing a therapist. It makes me angry seeing how a game about something as serious as depression can just say "you have to live with it". Depression is something YOU CANNOT just say go away to.\n\nNow I know the game is probably vouching for many playthroughs
hoursPlayed: and it wants you to find the "optimal path" to fighting depression
voteText: but the problem is that there IS NO SPECIFIC PATH to fighting depression. And giving the answer to people who may have depressio to just deal with it is the WRONG APPROACH.\n\nWith Depression
helpfulPercent: you have to be more careful in what you tell the public due to the numerous misconceptions about the disease. Depression is CURABLE
votesHelpful: it's something that could be fought with help. Giving an ending that says deal with it is not only infuriating to me as someone who has known and has had depression himself
votesTotal: but also infuriating because it sending the wrong message to people.\n\nNow what can I recommend to make the game more exact in how to treat depression and how to articulate depression better? I would make the story have branching paths
votesFunny: but have it only have one ending which is getting yourself cured. Giving the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that you just deal with it is NOT the way to do it. With a premise as important as this
commentsCount: you have to tell the right message and not muddle the message by adding mechanics that hinder it.\n\nSo that's what I think. Depression Quest is not something I would recommend listening to but would recommend actually playing to see what experiance you might actually get. From the looks of it
column16: there's a way to get to the right ending
column17: but giving an endng that just says to deal with it is not the way to go.\n\nTo all of those who have depression
column18: please seek help immideately. Dont be afraid to go to a psychiatrist and talking about it. The psychiatrist is payed to listen to you. Don't be afraid if he will started judging you or something
column19: because he wont. He will help you
column20: and will get you better.\n\nSpread the word that Depression is something you can FIGHT
column21: not just AVOID."

reviewText: The idea behind Depression Quest is something I have no problems with and is fairly solid. Making people aware of how difficult living with depression can be is really important and more people should be aware of it. However it's also important to take this 'game' at face value. It's at the most a choose your own adventure story with minimal end results. The creator made the right choice in releasing it for free, as it has nowhere near enough content to justify a price tag.\n\nWould I recommend people play this game, possibly yes, however for the sakes of the steam review system no. As good as it is,  it's very minimalistic and lacks decent content, it's very linear and when playing it makes you feel like actually the choices you make have little effect on the games outcome. It's also really only good for a single playthrough as results become predictable. Im sure eventually there will be a more fleshed out itteration of this game. However now isn't that time.

reviewText: I won't lie. I am a casual gamer. I have a small collection of games that I very much enjoy. I'm not competitive. I like story. And I like unique aesthetic. After all the hubbub that I probably don't need to mention, I decided to give this a shot. It couldn't be nearly as bad as everyone said, right? Well... Depression Quest has a unique aesthetic in that it doesn't have one at all. It is text. I can't even call this a Visual Novel since there are NO VISUALS. I have depression, yes. It's nice to see my illness exposed, but this is inappropriate. THIS IS NOT SUITABLE FOR STEAM. This is not a game. THIS IS NOT A GAME. Even though this is free, get a different game with mental illness as a theme, read a book, or perhaps talk to someone who actually has depression. This garbage makes Gone Home look like Demon's Souls.

reviewText: Okay, let me get this off my chest. This is not a game, this is an interactive Short Story.. My rationale for it being a non-game is that it has no gameplay just hyperlinks that can be done in so many different ways including powerpoint. I can't see how this got through greenlight or how it won awards especially over Papers Please.. Personally, I come from a family that does have Depression problems in it and this game while it gets some things right most other problems it doesn't. So don't buy the hype you see from these professional" reviewers.. It is just insane how they think this is a perfect way to understand depression. Its not. I still have my Psychology text books and those are more clearly defined and from personal experience as well.\n\nMy next problem is on the writing level.. there is no characterization
date: not even a very good idea of the feelings one experiences when being depressed. But it does get some right. It is very hard to even care about the protagonist or even the choices you make since the weight to them is painfully clear. Some more emotional weight and more atmosphere would have been better suited for the emotional impact. Heck it doesn't even have anything in the way of a hero's journey or even much depth of character.\n\nOverall
recommended: even though this is a free game its best to avoid this story and actually read up on depression and actually support those suffering from it. Encourage them to get the help they need even if they are afraid. Pro tip for the creator
hoursPlayed: more depth
voteText: more emotion
helpfulPercent: more characterization
votesHelpful: and more atmosphere. Plus researching and interviewing would help too.. That is my friendly advice from me to you writer to writer."

reviewText:
I could talk about how the awful writing, the unrealistic and the unfeeling characters and how the main guy or girl seems completely unwilling to help themselves. How I felt no attachment nor had any feelings towards the characters and how frushtrated I was that the text adventure completely striped me of all agency within it, granting me the illusion of choice without actually giving me choice at all.
I could talk about how the music is annoying, a harmless little melancholy drum beat that goes on and on whilst you are forced to read text wall after endless text wall and how that music becomes increasingly irrating.
I could even possibly give it credit for its portrayal of depression but even then the depressed can and do help themselves everyday, its hard but we do it, the main character in this did not and striping us of the options to be able to help ourselves is just straight up bad design
But instead the reason I think this is a piece of trash is simply that it is not a game.

I chose to not recommend" the game having in mind a gamer audience.

then i actually recommend that this is played.

Bad game.

Good depression awareness for public."

reviewText: [SERIOUS REVIEW] Look, I've been suffering from depression since the 6th grade, I can surely tell you that the answer to depression is not therapy, this game takes such a soft approach to depression. Realistically however, depression doesn't just go away, it comes in tremors, one day you'll be laughing with your friends and playing games, next day you'll be regretting life and considering suicide. The only way that I made it this far through my depression is because I don't want to end up like some relatives of mine, forgotten through time by those around them. The depiction of depression in this game makes it seem that everyday is spent in endless peryl and suffering, and it's always black and white and lethargic, however I can wholeheartedly vouch that it is not. In conclusion, they tried, but did not even come close.

reviewText:
Summary Of Everything
Representation of depression: Embarrasingly horrible.
Background music & sounds: A N N O Y I N G.
Game & storyline: Boring & not that interactive tbh.
Look: I could make a better game and I'm the least creative sh!t you'll ever meet.
Would I recommend? NOPE.


As someone currently struggling with depression, I find most of this game very controversial. Yes, it may be accurate in few areas, but it is also a very vague and inaccurate representation of someone with such a mind. We with depression DO like to hang out with friends and seek help. The answers were extremely pointed and were obviously only leading to one end. So basically, in summary, the representation of a mind with depression is appalling.

On top of this, the background noise/music/whatever was the most irritating thing I have ever had to listen to - and I've listened to Justin Bieber. It was EXTREMELY basic and could've had AT LEAST SOME effort put into it.

The game itself was just boring. A bunch of text with a few answers at the bottom of every second page? My five year old cousin could make that. There was nothing to interact with or to make the person playing feel like they were experiencing this all first hand.

Also, when you're making a game, PLEASE get some interesting pictures. Get something that will make your game look less like a grade 7 IT project and more like a developed, professional game.

reviewText:
Summary Of Everything
Representation of depression: Embarrasingly horrible.
Background music & sounds: A N N O Y I N G.
Game & storyline: Boring & not that interactive tbh.
Look: I could make a better game and I'm the least creative sh!t you'll ever meet.
Would I recommend? NOPE.


As someone currently struggling with depression, I find most of this game very controversial. Yes, it may be accurate in few areas, but it is also a very vague and inaccurate representation of someone with such a mind. We with depression DO like to hang out with friends and seek help. The answers were extremely pointed and were obviously only leading to one end. So basically, in summary, the representation of a mind with depression is appalling.

On top of this, the background noise/music/whatever was the most irritating thing I have ever had to listen to - and I've listened to Justin Bieber. It was EXTREMELY basic and could've had AT LEAST SOME effort put into it.

The game itself was just boring. A bunch of text with a few answers at the bottom of every second page? My five year old cousin could make that. There was nothing to interact with or to make the person playing feel like they were experiencing this all first hand.

Also, when you're making a game, PLEASE get some interesting pictures. Get something that will make your game look less like a grade 7 IT project and more like a developed, professional game.

reviewText:
Hard for me to recommend this 'game'-

While it has a lot of things that relate to how depression feels, I don't think anyone who hasn't experienced depression themselves could really understand. I could be wrong on that, but it's just how I feel.

That being said, I enjoyed the read- playing through a second time, making as many positive choices as possible to see how the outcome would be, it was an interesting experience to say the least.

That also being said, I want to say great work for the team who put this together- I just can't really recommend this to anyone.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely terrible. I hated playing this, but I played all the way through.

First off: Title is completely misleading, I was completely expecting to be playing an RPG but it turned out this wasnt an RPG... The entire game I thought was like a cinematic where you create the storyline for your character before you start the game. Extremely misleading...

Second off: There were a lot of parts where I just wanted to smash my girlfriend, but the game DID NOT ALLOW THIS, EXTREMELY UNREALISTIC. If I was super depressed or anything, I would just smash my girl and be done with my issues.

Third off: I dont understand quite why some of the options were completely unavailable to choose from: perhaps I was playing the game wrong? Missed the pre-requisites? Maybe I wasn't a high enough level and after the long cinematic I would be able to choose a class and go back to have those options available? No, not in this game, this game was not a game where you could do whatever you want..

My suggestion to the developer : Change the name of your game, I was not on a quest, I did not save the princess, I did not get any poonanny, I didn't make it to the highest level, and I didnt slay the ♥♥♥♥ing dragon - this is not a quest!!!!!!!

If you dont wanna change the name of the game, you might wanna make it so that after the whole depression storyline, you can actually move on to the quest and choose a class and ♥♥♥♥, but dont do like Rogue Warrior and Sorcerer either, that's too cliche, you should make it so you dont really have a class, but you choose what skills you wanna be good at, know what I mean?

Pros: awesome soundtrack - I personally downloaded the soundtrack and use it when I workout
beautiful quality images - I felt like I was actually watching netflix at one point when the netflix screen popped up

Cons: no real quests
no classes
no boss fights
no xp system
a lot of options unavailable
could not smash girl
could not get into hard drugs


I would NOT recommend this game to a friend. I would recommend it to someone who I really dislike though.
2/10

reviewText: The Name isn't the title of the game, It's what you feel when you play this game.

reviewText:
Grade Scale Notes: This review operates on a One-to-Ten rating scale for various segments.

1/10: Horrible.
3/10: Nothing interesting. Might have potential, but is weighed down (By glitches, poor/uninteresting design and controls, ETC)
5/10: Average
7/10: Well made
9/10: Stellar
I do not give 10/10's, as there is no such thing as perfection. I do not give 0/10's, unless the game truly lacks something. And I always round down.

Review Intro:

When I was in elementary school, I would read a few choose-your-own adventure books in the library. For vague reasons, a friend told me to try this game out and see what I thought of it.

Gameplay: 2.5/10

Depression Quest is not a game, it is instead a virtual Choose-your-own-adventure story that does not let you choose your adventure, as it will frequently provide you with many options that cannot actually be selected. This single fact made me lose interest rapidly. If the game had allowed you to select those options, but the results would vary based on the three stats displayed at the bottom of every page (Depression level, therapist level, and medication level), the game might take a turn for the better. The three options do change based on some available actions, but the fact that it means nothing is disappointing. The option for plugging a controller in is strange and entirely unneeded.

Gameplay Suggestions: Allow the ability to select options who's results vary based on the stats located at the bottom of the page: Depression Level, Therapist Level ( Which would include seeing a therapist, and one's relation with said therapist) and Medication level (level of medication in one's system at that time.). Do not deprive the player of their aility to choose: There is always a choice.

Graphics (For the sake of this particular review, this will include music): 1/10

I've never been a fan of grayscaled images. That comment aside, this program features limited visuals that are meant to go alongside the story text, but due to the nature of the layout these pictures fall to the wayside on longer text instances. The music is meant to set a sad mood, and ignoring the fact that slow piano music has become a staple for sad game moments, the lack of variety in music made things feel monotonous...The piano number is also boring, to be blunt.

Graphics Suggestions: Different music numbers to coincide with different events, that, like the singular piano number, are meant to envoke feelings. There are many kinds of sadness, there should be just as many sad music numbers. If the game is changed to feature more scenes and instances, have music that accompanies it: Music that shows joy, anger, defeat.

Story/Writing: I divide the Story/Writing into three categories. Theme, Characters, and Quality. The total score for writing is 5/30, or 1.6/10, rounded down.

Theme: 1/10

Depression is a serious topic. However, depression on it's own is not enough, thematically, for a game. We need to better see a gradual decent into the depths of sorrow, but being able to rise above and triumph over depression is just as satisfying as defeating the final boss in any other game. This game lacks any of those feelings, and in turn I felt nothing from the game.

Theme Suggestions: Make me feel something.

Characters: 3/10

The protagonist is unnamed, and meant to be an avatar for the player to see the world with. I did not once feel connected to the world or the plights of the protagonist. The reason for this is tied heavily to my comments in regards to 'gameplay'. We have Alex, your 'significant other', but we know very little about them, and less of the other minor characters such as Attic. Alongside the lack of noteworthy characters, the story does not make you feel for the characters already present.

Character Suggestions: Add additional characters. Usually an iffy topic for any story, but when your story lacks characters, you need a few more to bring life to the world. Provide us with more details of these characters; make us feel for these characters. Yes the story is about the protagonist, but those characters are a part of the protagonist's world. At present, they exist moreso to advance the story.

Writing Quality: 1/10

Depression Quest lacks it's quest.

I found the writing to be similar to a High Schooler's Biology essay: It might look proper, but there's no soul to it. It's also short.

On the first playthrough the protagonist broke up with Alex, and then a few turns later the story ended. On the second playthrough the protagonist went to a therapist and got some medications, and actually seemed to start to get better (which almost made me become interested in the story) and then a few turns later the story ended. If I decided to suffer a third time through, it would go on for a bit, and then the story would end.

THE STORY WOULD END. Yes, all stories have to end, but when the ending is Thank you for playing
date: we know this might not be the easiest game...". First off
recommended: game is the wrong word (see Gameplay review)
hoursPlayed: secondly you do not deprive the reader of the story's end unless you've crafted the story in such a way that it can be interpreted freely by the reader...which is not how a 'Choose-Your-Own-Adventure' works. You do not interprete the end because you found the end
voteText: and the end is not a message from the author
helpfulPercent:
it is THE END of the story.

Story Suggestions: Start over. That's all I can say.

Overal Game Score: By math

votesTotal: or 1.7/10. But my soul believes the score to be 1/10

reviewText:
I've never really written a review so please bear with me.

Honestly without even considering gamer-gate I'd give this game alone a 4/10

The whole story lacked any sort of real emotional words (whether that's intentional or not) and never really drew" me into the experience. On top of that for the first half of the game what seemed like wrong choices (since they were doing nothing) turned out to be right choices closer to the end of the game. The fact that seeing what I thought would be common sense and the right answer rejected and then picked up later sort of brought the feeling like I could have done better in the game even though
recommended: I had a near perfect game.\n\nI also had an issue with the music. I get that it was supposed to help greaten the story
hoursPlayed: or maybe even cover over it
voteText:
but  it wound up distracting me from the story. I of course didn't turn the music off out of fear that the generally labeled "sound" would somehow be important later in game (it wasn't). By the end of the game I was not only not affected by the music but I was out right sick of it.

Another issue is that some of the points are automatically crossed off. This lead to a more straight-forward feel to the game instead of the (hopefully) intended mood of it being a choose your own adventure. By the end of it I felt like there could have been a completely better and different game if you didn't focus on keeping the character so depressed for half the game.

So in summary I feel as though Depression Quest has a lacking storyline

reviewText:
This game was extremely simple. About an hour into the game, I figured out that the choices presented all had a very easy to predict path. I could be a loner at the party, or I could be cheery. Guess what made me sink deeper into a depression? That's right. The game is too easy to predict, so I didn't really enjoy, especially since I do have these thoughts. It tells me that I only have one way to go if I choose the choices I would, because it would be hopeless. I can respect what the creator was trying to do, but this is something extremely tricky to create a game out.

I'm even directing a play about depression and suicide, and it has been difficult. She goes with the stereotypes and connotations associated with depression, when there is a lot more that goes into it other than feeling hopeless. I would recommend that next time anyone makes a game that deals with that topic, they research the hell out of everything,

Overall:4/10
It's a fun-ish game to see what your playthrough will result in, but it isn't something to take seriously.

reviewText:
Played the flash version of this awhile back. Played this again to see if they’ve made any changes to the possible choices. From what I can tell, no changes were made and the decision making is still very contrived. Would hardly consider this a game about depression. If anything, I’d change the game’s name from “Depression Quest” to “Bob’s Quest, Who Happens to Have Depression With a Set of Very Specific Circumstances.”

The thing I hate about this the most (which I don't remember from the flash version) is the music. This works better without any music playing. The fact that it has the piano playing a tune that belongs in a funeral proceeding like that in the background is almost expecting things to turn out poorly.

3/10 - Would rather feed Cid bad fish and have Celes jump off the cliff instead.

reviewText: An incredibly simplistic interactive book that fails to provide any deeper understanding into an individual's plight with depression. The character comes across as more of a self-absorbed ♥♥♥♥ with no backbone, whom they try to give an illusion of having depression by greatly limiting any decisions made available to the character. reviewText: After hearing about the controversy, surrounding this game, I thought I would give it a try and form my opinion. I played the game for about twenty minutes, and then uninstalled it. The game struck me as boring, and lacking in any actual gameplay mechanics. I found little interest in the game's story, and the attempts at atmospheric piano music wore thin after it began to loop. As for how this game relates to helping you understand depression, I cannot say. I have never experienced depression myself, but it seems to me that the character in this game is incredibly fortunate to have so many supportive people when they have such a severe problem. Overall, I feel this game would be more approrpriate on a flash game site like newgrounds, as this is more of a choose your own adventure book then a game

reviewText:
Depression Quest is a game that delves into depression and its made in the style of a novel but will you want to read through it ?
In Depression Quest you play as a un named guy who one day gets Depression and the game tells a story on how he deals with depression. So how is this game ? Its not good its actually quite bad and i honestly dont suggest you play it. The game tries to make you depressed while playing it but all it does is bore you to death. The game is essiantly a novel with choice making which doenst affect the story at all. The game doenst have anything under its belt and all of is just bad. So ill just try to explain everything thats bad about it. The game is incredibly short. You can pretty much breeze through the game in under an hour which already as bad as it is. The games writing is awfull. It makes the game feel unfinished and its not very good. Overall there is another problem with it and that the choices dont affect the story which is stupid which revolves around choices. Overall the only saving grace is that the game is free which all i can say about it. Depression Quest is a boring mess you should only play if youre incredibly bored and dont have a better game to play. I give Depression Quest a 4/10

reviewText:
Gameplay: 1/10

There... isn't any gameplay, really. It doesn't seem like any of your choices really do much of anything, and since there's also no ending, there's no point/motivation anyway. It's essentially just randomly clicking links until you get bored. It's extremely short too; when it finished, I hadn't even reached an hour of play time.

Audio: 1/10

The audio was just annoying. It's described as being an important part of the experience, but all it is is really plain and awkwardly slow piano music that tries way too hard to sound sad. There was also audio of people talking, which was... okay, I guess. The sound all sounded a little off but I assume that was on purpose.

Graphics: 0/10

The only graphics were small grainy photographs that appeared over each wall of text. Even without the filters, they look like bad amateur photography" taken with an old webcam. This contributed to the unprofessional feel of the game.

Story: 0/10

It's aimless. There's no plot. The pacing is really quick
date: and you find your character suddenly go from miserably depressed to "barely depressed" in a span of five minutes. A lot of your choices have no real bearing on what will happen anyway. We aren't at any point made to care about this character
recommended: so we're stuck lugging through as a guy we don't care about moans about how miserable his life is. I don't know what emotions we were supposed to be feeling throughout the course of this game
hoursPlayed: but I assume "annoyance" and "boredom" are not on the list.\n\nIt's also not an accurate portrayal of depression. It's so much more multifaceted than it's portrayed here
voteText: and it's obvious that the developer has either never experienced depression or was trying to portray a blatantly fake
helpfulPercent:
one-dimensional depression stereotype.

Writing: 0/10

Since this is a choose your own adventure book rather than a game

votesTotal: imagine everything that good writers do; then
votesFunny:
imagine that the writer aimed to do exactly the opposite. The Choose Your Own Adventure books in the kids section at the library are more thought-provoking and engaging.

Overall: -10/10

Yes

reviewText:
This game isn't fun. Its not meant to be fun. I don't even know that its meant to be a game. It really doesn't need to be on Steam.

It is a glimpse at the average year of someone with depression.

Its much too similar to my own life.

Its also way too short. It fails to really shows highs and lows, but it does touch them. Losing sight of friends, unable to focus on projects, the fear  and anxiety that comes with trying to find help.

I'm not going to allow the recent drama surrounding the author to tarnish the intention of this interactive adventure, but I can honestly say I probably wouldn't have heard of it other wise.

I congratulate them on attempting to bring awareness to a mental disease that plagues way too many. However, I wish it was grittier. Not everyone gets it as easy as the character in the story. Some people worked very hard just to get to his level of listlessness and confusion. There is so much more that COULD be done here.

reviewText:
I will be honest, I only heard of this game because of the contreversy surrounding the creater. But amid the turmoil, I found myself somewhere I didn't want to be -a particularly hateful state of mind. I've said things I am not proud of and decided to cool off and approach the axis of this whole ordeal with the presence of mind to be as objective and purely observant as possible, and leaving behind any intial personal feelings and bias so that I may gain a perspective. I am not a professional video game critic in the least bit, but I do write and edit people's stories as a hobby, so I like to think that I have a credible right to review this.

With all that said, and after playing through, I do no recommend this game.

Foremostly -and this critical point has been brought up before- can this really be considered a game? It is a digital choose-your-own-adventure novel that feels like it belongs to a site dedicated to ametuer fiction or to an art blog like Deviantart -not a video game distributer. I feel Depression Quest would of been more appropriate and more well received if it were distributed on an art site where skill progression and opinionated pieces are welcome. But Steam brings with it a great expectation, and you can be hard hit by the community if you fall short of it with even the greatest intentions. There just isn't a place for a glorified book in steam, and I feel that alone warrants my negative recommendation.

But beyond where and how the developers chose to distribute Depression Quest, the game falls flat in a number of ways. Despite a fairly strong start, the protagonist becomes insufferable and I find it impossible to sympathize half the time, and this is due to, for the most part, the constant repitition of the same theme of I'm sad". The chapters blend together as a blur of melancholy and it becomes increasingly difficult for me to go on as it progresses to the point that it is so dull it becomes a chore to keep on reading. Each page felt like a rehash of the previous with a different background and theme like a depression Madlib. My determination to see it through to the end to gain perspective on the situation was the only thing that kept me going

reviewText: In short: it’s not very good. From download completion to game end, it took me one hour to complete (note that this was with frequent breaks for me to vent to friends on skype chat about the experience. Other people I know said they finished the game in 25 minutes). The art design of the game was questionable and didn’t match up with the game very well, the music was ill-fitting and cliche, the game design was ineffective at achieving its goals of reflecting the mindset of a person suffering from depression (which I know from firsthand experience), the writing was bland and there were some choices regarding presentation that were extremely baffling.\n\nFor a more thorough explanation of the problems I had with this game, read here: http://daemonpro.tumblr.com/post/95265081744/in-this-post-a-douchenozzle-who-has-never-made-a-game

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: THIS IS NOT A GAME !!! It is a poorly written ''choose your own adventure'' novel disguised as a ''game''.

There is no gameplay, there is no artwork, there is no replay value, there are no models, there are no animations. Just one wall of text after another. Hell, at least in many ''choose you own adventure'' novels there is very decent artwork to be found. If we are going to kid ourselves into thinking depression quest is a video game we might as well delude ourselves into thinking novels are video games too. Also, this game is incredibly short. I could probably create a better, similar HTML hyperlinks flash ''game'' in a single overnight sitting.

Do not encourage misleading half ♥♥♥♥♥ titles, BOYCOTT THIS!
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you want a better story about depression, go play The Cat Lady here on steam or GOG.com. Link is provided here:http://store.steampowered.com/app/253110/

The Cat Lady tackles what the author here is trying to convey in a much more engaging way that makes use of the medium.

Lets talk about this game. I didn't find myself engaged. Engaged being the key word here, its not fun because there is no reason to invest yourself in it. You're thrust into a role, given a plot-dump, and expected to make decisions accordingly. The story itself is incredibly lackluster, and i've seen other games deal with this topic in much more subtle, interesting ways. See The Cat Lady and something like Silent Hill 2 or Amnesia: A machine for pigs for better examples.

Even at its free price tag, I'm afraid to report that this is a game that take a concept that has a huge potential for being interesting, and squanders that opportunity through bad UI and a boring story.

Play The Cat Lady instead.

reviewText: Depression Quest, is not a game. It is an experience. Unfortunately, the experience is more akin to sitting in a DMV waiting line and reading the dictionary at the same time, only even more tedious. First and foremost, the main portion (and by this I mean all of it) is reading and choosing some action" that leads to... more reading! . Yes! I totally want to read some lame story to pass the time instead of
recommended: PLAYING something. This could be forgivable if not for the fact that the story isn't even that good to begin with. And by that
hoursPlayed: I mean that I enjoyed reading Wuthering Heights more than this story. Wuthering ♥♥♥♥ing Heights was more interesting than this. What really bothered me the most about this was that the choices you were given almost never go through because your "character" is just too full of self-pity to do anything you say. Way to make me feel like I have ANY control whatsoever over a gaming experience.\n\nImagine if an actual game did this. Suppose you're playing some Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

reviewText:
Where to start. This game looks like it was written in Flash by someone unfamiliar with how to create a project in Flash. Seriously, I've seen students who - in their first few weeks of learning how to create Flash projects - had created something far, far better than this.

The writing and design of this title is simply poor. Choices, when prompted, often don't make any sense, even in the context of psychology (not to mention game design). e.g. if someone doesn't like cats it doesn't mean they're going to get depressed - dog people exist too. This game does nothing for the great cat people/dog people divide in our society - instead of taking the opportunity to mend fences, the author insists that people who don't like cats are depressed loners, longing to slit their wrists.

As someone who has suffered on and off again with depression my entire life, along with extensive counseling and even some psychology coursework, I went into this game expecting to understand the subject matter better than most. Instead I'm given a series of overly simplified, trite choices created by a team who didn't understand the first step in game design: understand your subject matter. If you're going to make a first person shooter, you need to spend your time looking at other first person shooters, learning what makes them good and bad, then try to create a game that's compromised of more good elements than bad. When you're going to make a game dealing with psychology,.. you damn well better have a firm grasp of psychology. Anyone who was actually depressed would likely end up getting more depressed by playing" this
date: thanks to the boorish way the authors deal with their subject.\n\nI recommend in the strongest possible terms that everyone simply avoid this title at all costs
recommended: it has no redeeming value whatsoever."

reviewText:
This 'game' is not a game.

It's text-based and basically you read long paragraphs about the character, who you are supposed to reflect yourself in to, and then click various hyperlinks to see where the story goes from there. In the beginning there are a few hyperlinks within the post that tell you a little about your relationships with your parents, brother, and your girlfriend, as well as your job. After this, it talks about the following days with hyperlinks on what to do next at the bottom. This is where I have my problem.
I have depression. Out of all of these 'choices', normally one or two of them are in red and have a strike through them meaning that these are options that you cannot do because your character is simply incapable of doing because of their depression. The other choices? One is the 'right choice' of doing something that brings them out with their friends or to work on their side project, and the other two are normally 'withdraw from social interaction', 'nothing, I don't want to talk about my problems,' or, 'I'm going to go back to sleep.' Most of the 'bad options' made the person with depression seem lazy and that people with depression just don't want to deal with what's bothering them. Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me?
Depression is different for everyone and what this game seems to recommend is to get out and do things. Sure, that helps a little, but it never gets to its core. Not everyone is going to get help from that, and not everyone gets better by taking anti-depressants or medication.
I'm offended by this game. After playing it I felt angry. Clearly, they have no idea what depression really is.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game isn't a game at all. It lacks content, the subject around the plot is incredibly mundane and not enjoyable. Finally, this looks like a game fabricated in the 80's. Text based adventure games haven't aged well, but this game wouldn't pass the bar back in the 80's.\n\nVideo games are supposed to be an escape from reality, not a center focus around some of the worst parts of it. The reason why this game doesn't fit the bill is simply because of that. Depression is not a good plot for a video game. Maybe a subplot for a specific character, but this doesn't sell. If you're going to make a game based around a mental illness, then I first suggest that you don't do that and instead make a game that is actually enjoyable no matter who's playing it.. I've never suffered from depression, so this game is foreign to me and I cannot connect with the main character(s) at all. That is another point where this game falls so incredibly short. Maybe this would've been alright to donate to a hospital that deals with mental illness, but even at that this game" would need a massive graphical (sorry
date: text based adventures dont cut it) and content overhaul.\n\n0/10"

reviewText:
This game isn't fun. Its not meant to be fun. I don't even know that its meant to be a game. It really doesn't need to be on Steam.

It is a glimpse at the average year of someone with depression.

Its much too similar to my own life.

Its also way too short. It fails to really shows highs and lows, but it does touch them. Losing sight of friends, unable to focus on projects, the fear  and anxiety that comes with trying to find help.

I'm not going to allow the recent drama surrounding the author to tarnish the intention of this interactive adventure, but I can honestly say I probably wouldn't have heard of it other wise.

I congratulate them on attempting to bring awareness to a mental disease that plagues way too many. However, I wish it was grittier. Not everyone gets it as easy as the character in the story. Some people worked very hard just to get to his level of listlessness and confusion. There is so much more that COULD be done here.

reviewText: This game fails in all it intends to be; it's not interactive, it's not entertaining nor is it particularly well written. It doesn't give depression more publicity, nor does it really make anyone who doesn't suffer from depression understand it better. It is, at best, an insensitive attempt to create an interactive story around a buzzword. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone, as if you have depression it will make you feel worse, and if you don't it will build upon the stereotypes society already has built up around the illness. If you want to play a thoughtful game about the subject, please go and buy Actual Sunlight. It is much better. Please, if you feel you're suffering from depression, reach out to someone, and if you know someone else who is, encourage them. Don't be like this game.

reviewText:
I've played this game for a bit on the Depression Quest site. And I thought the title was strange. Am I on a quest to being depressed?
There is absolutely no gameplay whatsoever. You just click hyperlinks and just keep reading. Think Homestuck, but no interesting visuals, no engaging dialogues/text to read. You can't really seem to 'connect' with the main character (depressed you).
I like visual novels. And I've played quite a bit of date-simulation games mainly for the pretty visuals.
But 'Depression Quest' isn't a visual novel; it's literally a novel digitized with some somber music playing on a loop. It's so full of text I doubt anyone who's looking to play an actual game would want to spend a quarter of an hour on this. You'll prefer reading all the books in Skyrim.
You get options:
> Continue with 'game'
> Quit and play something more worthwhile
Some options being crossed-out so I see no point in even listing them as a choice.
I'm much in support of helping people rid of depression but this isn't helping me or anybody i know who has depression. I'd very much prefer not to waste my time playing this 'game' and actually talk to my depressed friend.
Depression Quest lives up to its name in getting you Depressed. For real.

reviewText: I do not recommend this as a game, and as any other form of medium it is only subpar.  The writing is average, with thankfully few-no mistakes (the texts are humorously mispelled at times).  The red text options are unfortunately a slight against the game I have when there are 3-4 good options and it only lets you select one.  With some love, this could be made both enjoyable and whatever it qualifies as currently.  Anything on Steam that begins by saying it is not enjoyable does not belong, in my opinion.  It has potential, but it does not pull my heart strings or entertain me.  Unfortunate failure of an idea with potential.

So, as some one who has had depression problems in the past, I can safely say this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This is nothing like what I went trough, I realize that depression is different for everyone but.... for ♥♥♥♥s sake the game treats it like an icurable plague. Real depression is taking ADHD meddice for months in country which completely alien to you, with no friends, difficulty speaking the native language and a dysfunctional family that constantly fights over child support.

♥♥♥♥ man, if I had a better relations with my family and at least one or two friends back when I had depression problems....Thank god that I actually tried to find help.

So...Rating?

reviewText:
The concept(s) or intention(s) behind the 'game' is/are probably be good, but as realistic Depression Quest might get, I don't feel like I get a better understanding of what depression might feel like. I also find it a little confusing that some of the options are simply just crossed out even though they're still listed, like it's not really an option anyway, which makes it feel like a depressed person can't or won't try to make it better, or even reach out for help.

And as someone has already mentioned in their review, the reason(s) behind and the sereverity of the depression the main character suffers are a bit unclear, because the main character seems to be having pretty good conditions to live under.

The design also looks like it was made by someone who just learned to code and wanted/needed some practice, or someone who  wanted something to publish and just put some text together with a few photos, with a minimum amount of effort put into it. In its current shape, Deprssion Quest would've been better off being launched as a website, or a web/browserbased game, rather than a full scale game suitable to be played through platforms like Steam.

All in all, the game could really need some more improving. And if you ask me, no price is the best price for this game.

reviewText:
The best way to do this game justice is to look at a pile of ♥♥♥♥ with a few roses hidden inside it. A lot of the story seems like projection of the author and a misunderstanding of how deppression works on the brain and through processes. There are, however, a few very good points that perfectly outline what and how deppression is, but only if you are able to analyze the game without your own bias. The author tried to use situations and telling (instead of showing) how the character feels to try and manipulate the player into understanding deppression, yet she *completely* missed the point. If she truly wanted to make people understand deppression she would've used the mentioning and not mentioning of in game concepts to manipulate the player into looking at a 90/10 world of happiness/sadness and making the player only look at the sad. That would be a true work of art, unfortunately this is just angsty-projection with big words thrown in to sound smart and tell instead of show.


2/10 Is harmful to the understanding of how deppressed people's mindset and feelings. Is also terribly written at times and has typos.

reviewText:
Is there any better way for a game to start than by disclaimer it is not for the faint of heart, yet it fails to depict meaningful drama or genuine negative consequences of depression? Besides occasional lines of dialog how I am horrible because depression and someone cannot take it any more and suddenly we're up to something else? What borderlines irony is the foreword of the game is perhaps the most enjoyable part of the game, since it feels like the developers knew their onions; they laud and dazzle how it focuses on depression... by simply telling what it is. You have depression. Everything is great but you just have depression and then things falls apart and end of story - or not quite but more like sort of but not kind of. Boo said the ghost of hung criminal at the gallows.

Unless there is some new, booming market for choose-your-own-depression books, since choose-your-own adventure books usually operate on different matters at hand.

If the game simply gave basic framework for interactivity to properly explore, shallowly telling what is going on with no further investment is not bad idea. That is assuming there is more interactivity besides click for another skip of text that makes me want to read an actual book. I do not shun the idea of interactive media branching beyond common ideas" for video games

reviewText: Calling Depression Quest a video game and releasing it on a platform like Steam seems like a bit of a misnomer, as this is little more than a series of inter-connected pages that could (and perhaps should) just as well be linked in a side-bar of someone's blog.\nThat said, to review Depression Quest on its merits, it is not a poorly written title. The narrative is cohesive, if restrictive, and progresses naturally. This is, however, where the title's merits both begin and end. The graphics, which are mostly nonexistent, consist of a few pictures strewn across the top of the page that sometimes relate to the topic at hand. Depression Quest is at its core a text-based adventure, however in 2014 we should expect a little more out of rudimentary game design.\nThe gameplay is typical of Choose Your Own Adventure novels (and would perhaps be a better classification than video game), and while it lacks any kind of flair, your choices are made precise and clear. They are, however, limited in scope, which is Depression Quest's major downfall. Your choices in each scenario basically boil down to Let me wallow deeper into depression
date: or Let me try to climb out of this pit of depression
recommended: and with no inventory to speak of and a very limited status indicator (You are depressed." "You are kind of depressed." "You are severely depressed.")
hoursPlayed: you not only very quickly learn how to game the system

reviewText: Interactive Fiction was one of the first genres of videogames that I ever got seriously into. The reasons why are mainly by accident: I was a pre-teen looking for fun things play online that had a little more depth than crappy flash games. A google search landed me on an Infocom database site, and learning how to use WinFrotz, I entered the magical world of text based, parser command games. Zork, Andrew Plotkin, Emily Short, Chickzilla, Slouching Towards Bedlam, Aaron A. Reed (Blue Lacuna), Taco Fiction. These games and authors of games shaped what I know, love, and enjoy from the genre.\n\nPlaying Depression Quest was difficult for me. The reason being because it does so many things that turn Interactive Fiction players like me off. One of the biggest mistakes was doing the age old WOT, or Wall of Text mistake. The game likes to open, and continue, to barrage you with walls of text, and this makes for terrible flow in IF games. No one wants to sit and read a wall of text every time they make a decision. It's a typical amateur IF game mistake that I'm surprised has been allowed in a game published on Steam. The second biggest issue with this game is the lack of choice. I get that part of the reason that half of the choices are crossed out and unusuable are because they are the rational" or "good" choices that a person who does not suffer depression would typically choose. But that's not a good excuse for crappy design
date: because I am no longer playing the game: the game is instead playing itself. The only feeling of "helplessness" that Depression Quest seems to evoke is that of surrendering all choice to the game. Which is another amateur IF mistake.\n\nAnd yes
hoursPlayed: that is the point of Depression Quest. To take away your choice because when you suffer from depression you don't have one. But that's where the word "game" comes into question here: is Depression Quest a game? The reason I know it is not
voteText: is simple.\n\nIt says so right in the WoT introduction: "This game is not meant to be a fun or lighthearted experience." It's not meant to be fun. So of course how can it be a game? Nor is it a CYOA (choose your own adventure)
helpfulPercent: because despite the feature of choice
votesHelpful: the choices ultimately effect literally nothing
votesTotal: and are always extremely similar to one another.\n\nSo why is it on Steam? Well I guess it's in an effort to raise awareness that Depression is a real problem. So is it a good education tool? I don't really think so; it doesn't do it's job as well as it should. There were games that made me feel like the person I was playing easily

reviewText:
This is utter tripe. Not even as an avid adventure gamer could I find enjoyment out of this.

I suffer from depression and almost a year ago I ended up in the hospital due to it, but this experience, and i use that term lightly, was not something I could relate to.

The thing about depression, and it's associated pain is that it's individualized, no one will know what it is like to be in your shoes, and a video game about your experience won't help anyone come to any realizations.

This doesn't show what depression is like, nothing can and since everyone experiences it differently, I suggest you pick up a psychology book if you really want to understand depression.

There isn't much here of substance, it's all very arbitrary and lacking. It looks like a 5 year old designed it and athestically it looks like it was made with windows 95 in mind.

Ironically, the game made me more depressed than I already was, but depressed in a different way... depressed that this made it through greenlight. This doesn't belong here. It's not a game.

The entire time I was playing it, I was pigeon holed into making choices I didn't want to make, and as a person with depression many of the choices that were blocked for me were choices that I would make. I felt a strong sense of a victim mentality from the author".

Just like anyone with depression - We are but a victim of our own minds. She is a victim
recommended: and it doesn't sound like she has enough of a grasp on depression to be trying to educate others on it. Having depression doesn't make you a good teacher on the subject.\n\nThere isn't much to be had here
hoursPlayed: it's basically a choose your own adventure book
voteText: except you can't really make your own choices. Only the choices of the author. Which is the point
helpfulPercent: I get it - but it is poorly done.\n\nThumbs down."
