reviewText: It's hard to review this for 2 reasons. 1 is obviously all the controversy surrounding it makes it hard for anyone to take any review seriously, and 2 because it's not even really a game. I don't mean because there's no graphics, swordplay, puzzles, platforming, etc, etc, I still play zork on dosbox. I say that because it's more of a story of someone ELSE'S battle with depression, which is a serious problem I won't make fun of. You aren't given options that you'd take, you're forced into the same pattern of spiraling depression everytime which kind of gives the impression that it's hopeless, as if it didn't already feel like that. I've battled depression since my father died when I was 11, dealt with it still when I was 15 and my grandfather passed away from cancer, then at 19 when I was diagnosed with cancer, then for the next 14 months as I watched two close friends lose their fight with cancer. I know depression, my depression, but that doesn't mean I can tell anyone else what it's like or how to deal with it. My way was to open up to my friends and family (Drake, Mar, Crim, if you guys read this know you've probably saved me a couple of times when I was in a down mood just by bringing in some normalcy and letting me know there are people that care) but I know that's not an option for a lot of people. It was actually impossible for me to come out and talk to my mom about it, I had to write a note on the computer and leave it there for her to find. If you suffer depression, this game won't help you. If you know someone that's depressed or that you THINK might be depressed, this game won't help you.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not a fan of Zoe Quinn.

Is it weird that the story describes me so well, yet has so many flaws to it that I don't understand? It's like as if they have picked at my brain and took my life apart but added extra things to it to spice it up a bit, like parents that care or a job that I can sustain but I hate?

I've only been through a bit of the game and it has turned out okay. To be honest, even though it's a text based adventure, it feels like there is just TOO much text. It branches off important subjects that you don't know properly, like your relationship with your girlfriend Alex, your parents, your job, your brother that you're jealous of, etc. when it feels like it shouldn't really be describing each important subject with such detail. They should have just added minor explanations of certain things to help you become acquainted with the character that you are portraying, rather than create entirely new stories out of them that make it hard to catch up with and remember.

The idea of depression being different for everyone is both true and false, and they do have that kinda knotted down properly in the beginning of the game with an explanation, but I don't think they should say to stop playing it immediately if you are suicidal or anything close simply because it's a falsity of something relevant to you.

I like the idea of the game to help explain to people not suffering from depression what it's like, but it just doesn't fit well. It says that it's not an explanation or detail of depression because it varies between people, but it nails it down to just one type of depression, contradicting itself in the process of the entire game.

reviewText:
This game is the video game equivalent of valium, and is extremely offensive to someone like me.

As a sufferer of deep depression, the creator of this game is so far off base. Depression is not you feeling sad or upset that you're behind on that big project, or worried that your girlfriend might not be completely happy with your relationship. Depression is a numbness. There are days when leaving the house feels like the biggest accomplishment on the planet. There are no distractions from depression. You can't just get on Twitter or your email in hopes to forget about it. There is no blocking it out. And no matter what, you put on the bravest of faces, and you hide your condition.

Zoe Quinn, you did a horrible disservice to the gaming community and sufferers of depression.

reviewText:
I love this game 10/10 z0mg.
No, joking.
Let me explain why it's bad.
1. It's practically a pointless game with no happy endings. Literally anything that you do leads up to you becoming insanely depressed.
2. It's not even a game, it's a book with buttons.
3. It's dependent on the program the developer used, node-webkit, which is a make-shift web browser. Gee, that's putting a lot of effort in.
4. 5 minutes in and I wanted to blow my brains out.
5. It's a sad excuse of a game.
6. I literally choose the most depressing answers because it's a 'Depression Quest'. It took me 5 minutes.
7. The developer's point was to make a game that isn't 'fun'. He did it, but he forgot one thing - if a game isn't 'fun', it isn't worth jack squat.
Why Steam even let it get published as a F2P game, let alone be highly rated by Greenlight (if it even had one)? I don't know. But for your own good, do NOT download this game, let alone play it.

... But hey.
At least the uninstall option worked.

reviewText:
I'll admit, when I first downloaded this game, I thought it was going to be much worse than it actually was.

As far as games go, you could definitely do worse, especially since some of those worse games would actually cost you money.

However, the writing style feels a bit sloppy. The main character is described as sparingly as possible early on, to make him/her a blank slate for the player to put themselves in his/her shoes. And then the writers screwed that up by giving the main character a family and girlfriend, which requires him/her to be a definite person seperate from player. You can't have a character that you make your own and have the same character be defined by the writer, because odds are, the two ideas of what the character should be won't mesh.

I'll be generous and give it a 7/10.

reviewText: I've played through the entirety of the game" and honestly  I can not recommend this to anyone. Overall it is very poorly written with numerous spelling and punctuation mistakes. The story is very dull and to be frank quite contrived. Each section has multiple options where the majority of the time you can not select a number of them which completely ruins your immersion in the story
date: for example at one point there are 6 options available but you are only allowed to click 1. This turns this multiroute “game” into a fairly linear story. Most of the remaining options are either ridiculous or completely unrealistic. I don’t know how many times the main protagonist is with his girlfriend and you are not given the option to discuss things with her honestly up until the end of the game where the character is already well on his way to recovery. On top of all this the game doesn’t even achieve that which it sets out to do. It in no way displays what life is like if you are living with depression. Instead all it does is turns depression into a type of gameshow and if you choose the right option you get a reward (in this case you start to get better). It fails to show just how grim the world can appear to be when you suffer from the illness. All it really shows is a very self absorbed person (the protagonist) as he goes through his life only focusing on himself and not taking other peoples feelings into consideration (example being his time spent with his girlfriend). Maybe it would have come across differently if it was written by a better author
recommended: but that is not the case and as it stands it is miles short of completing it’s goal. But I will give credit where credit is due

reviewText:
I was (And still am) diagnosed with moderate-to-severe depression. While it has been getting better, I can entirely say this experience was complete and utter garbage.

How it handles something as permeating as depression is shameful at best and downright ham-handed at worst, shoehorning in options some people take, but then crossing them out in what I can only assume is their way of saying people who are really depressed don't make them. Some victims don't just shut themselves in, and this story seems to be saying that all of them do. In addition, depression is usually a slow fadeout. It doesn't just ♥♥♥♥ing appear in less than a day, and getting rid of it can take months at best, years at worst.

Then, the ending which claims it is a constant battle is an absolute slap in the face. We've been so hilariously unrealistic so far, why didn't you go that final ♥♥♥♥ing mile and make our protagonist suddenly all better, ready to face the world with his arsenal of rainicorns and unibows? Did you waste it on your Watch Netflix and cry" scenes?

I could say so much about this game
date: about how badly it does what it set out to do
recommended: how I completely loathe the developer and the scandal parade behind her
hoursPlayed: but I'll just stop at this:\n\nThis is not depression. This is a Social Justice Warrior's depression fantasy. And that's dangerous."

reviewText:
There is a lot of flak for this game and it's creator. I decided to avoid reading reviews and just dive in.

Depression Quest plays like an old choose-your-adventure book. You play as a depressed man and are given different choices each passing day. Some choices can be unpickable based on the mental state of the protagonist.

All in all, there are a few different endings but the game itself is very repetitive. The protagonist is a pathetic whiner who is completely unlikable.

I talked about this game with my girlfriend who claims to have suffered from depression. I told her that the game was uninspired and the protagonist an unlikable ♥♥♥♥. She got really premenstrual about this and whined about being intolerant" and not understanding what a crippling disease depression supposedly is.

Needless to say
date: we're no longer together. Anyone who's half-sane knows depression is not a REAL disease anyway.\n\nI'll give it a generous 2/10."

reviewText:
Thought I would review this game to get an alternate opinion of it.

Depression Quest is an interactive fiction game and not a modern one. It is in the vein of early computer games that were entirely text-based and derived from narratives. I think that is one of the reasons reviews are mixed on it. It doesn't fit the mold of what a modern" computer game is. Us old fart garmers will remember this type of gaming experience with fondness.

That being said
date: I can really only reccommend  the game for people who want to experience or learn about clinical depression or people who want to deal with their clinical depression in a positive way.\n\nIt is ingenious in its audacity and for tackling an often overlooked mental disease. It is innovative for its attempt to recreate the experience of a disease at a very realistic level. All the little things are there
recommended: such as the thought among many depressives that they don't actually have a disease when they are able to deal with it effectively (yes
hoursPlayed: that is a real thing) or excusing your tiredness for simply being tired
voteText: instead of the effects of a disease. Effects on concentration
helpfulPercent: focus
votesHelpful: seeking diversion (as a result of the disease
votesTotal: not as a way to find enjoyment as it is with many people)
votesFunny: social anxiety
commentsCount: interpersonal relationships
column16: and others are all modeled. It takes the form of a choose-your-own-adventure (as interactive fiction generally is) and so there is some replay value to it. I personally played it several times and
column17: since I don't know how the different paths of the game are determined
column18: it's actually kind of fun (yes
column19: in that ruminating depressive sort of way!) to tease out how the choices are rendered.\n\nThis is a game that does not have a wide appeal and is a very niche product. It is a game that has a therapeutic effect for suffers and/or is a way for the curious to "play" with the disease and challenge some preconceptions of yours or your preconceptions of those who suffer from the disease. If you are even remotely interested or intrigued
column20: I'd suggest it because it is free. Just realize that the "fun" of the game is derived from  learning about something
column21: not derived from entertainment."

reviewText:
Product received for free

For the record, I'm only typing this cause my Black ops 3 needed an update.

So I came across this game while over a friends house. After looking at masterpieces on the steam store such as Anime tank dating sim, Gabe Newell simulator, Shower with your dad simulator, and other works of pure art we stumbled across this game. Which I placed on my wishlist right next to Shower with your dad simulator. I then forgot about it for the rest of the day until around 11 that night. I was up doing who gives a ♥♥♥♥, when for some reason I had a craving.

Like you that craving you have when you want to play or watch something dark, or funny, or warm hearted, or whatever. Well I was craving something depressing. Something to kill my spirits and make me sit in the corner of my dark room thinking of how insignificant everything is in the grand scheme of things. And with that I reminded of Depression Quest. I wasn't expecting anything crazy, just something to make me feel weak and tired emotional, to help me sleep.

So I booted it up and pressed play, and the first thing I noticed was that the game had the names of the people who worked on the game on the left side of the screen, and there was one name that caught my eye, Zoe Quinn. reviewText:
The game has an understanding of how a person with depression can react to things but doesn't take some things into consideration. I feel it can be a hard read mostly due to the length. I don't think a lot of people can really relate with it since they will be in varying situations. I would have prefered if the game featured more than one music track since looping one can get kind of irratating. As a tool to teach others about depression I don't know how effective it would be and it feels more like a depression questionnaire that you would take on a site then a game.

As someone who was diagnosed with depression I could relate to parts but I feel a few things should be mentioned. Antidepressants are not always the best solution, in my experience I kept having to switch between meds to find which worked best since some cause really bad nausea, insomnia, and mood swings. I can't speak much on therapy since I only went in for a few sessions and would constantly put off or forget my sessions. And for those that don't have people in their lives to talk to it is worth noting that you can find support groups that you can talk to. I always found it easier to talk to people I didn't know about my issues since I felt less worried about being judged.

Overall I think if you have depression you would understand some of the choices you are presented with but if you are trying to understand someone else's depression it might be a bit harder. I liked that some options were crossed out but I feel an explaination on why you aren't up to that choice would be better suited. The game was kind of long winded and I feel that it could have been said with fewer words and would still have surmised the point it was aiming at.

reviewText: Impossible to relate to. This guy is not depressed, he's just unhappy. In reality you don't make one simple mistake and it drives you into spiraling depression leaving you unable to interact with people, have fun or function in daily life. That's what happens in this game: he makes one simple mistake that anyone can make and goes from being moderately depressed to deeply depressed (there is an ingame tracker). Real depression is NOTHING like that! It takes a lot more than that to actually make depression worse keeping in mind that depression numbs your emotions so you don't care about stuff as much. You can actually make him reach the highest level of depression in 3 steps making the same mistakes any person could do in one day and brush it off and walk away. Whoever made this game has never had depression, doesn't understand it and is not in any position to be educating anyone on it.

I would not recoment Depression Quest as in my opinion it do's not depict what deppression accuretly is.

No one sould ever play this intreactive story inless its purely for weird entertainment.

I personally think it depicts deppression in a horrible manner rather than highlight Self-Help
That is the only way of helping as YOU alone can be the only one to help make your own life better,
It would rather seem to me that this game alone can cause you to feel crap and gernraly missrable.

My self help tips for deppression is “Try your hardist to make your own life happy” at any-cost,

So live your life and get active, Do gardening, help people, Get a dog (Cats are deppressing.)
Go long walks at night time spend your time with someone... anyone.
Set yourself goals and comple them one by one.

Ending your own life is not a answer as you take your deppression with you to a lovely place called hell.

~Husky~

reviewText:
This game sucks, for multiple reasons.

1.It's too easy. Battling depression is no where near this easy in real life. Literally almost every choice you can ever choose from is Stay inside/be a lonely loser/don't socialize/don't be happy" or "Go outside/talk to people/do something that makes you happy" This game does not properly portray just how difficult it is to be motivated or do things that will improve your life while depressed.

2.It's too short. Over the course of half and hour and one minute I was able to beat the game twice
recommended: look at the play times of the other reviewers. The game is just too short. Depression is a serious
hoursPlayed: usually life long thing
voteText: something that can't be conveyed in a game that's not even half an hour long. And no
helpfulPercent: just because the epilogue says depression lasts a long time and the game takes place over a long time does not make the fact that it's too short okay. A game such as this show what depression is like in an immersive and realistic way that draws people in
votesHelpful: which leads to my next point...\n\n3.The game isn't fun. It has no real gameplay. Yes I know depression isn't fun but games are supposed to be played. Playing involves fun. The fact that the game says it's supposed to be something other than fun does not matter. Just because a videogame has a real meaning doesn't mean it shouldn't have real gameplay or be fun. A good game developer would use the gameplay to convey the message! A good game developer doesn't shy away from gameplay just because it doesn't fit the story or the meaning of the game. No
votesTotal: a good game developer would make the gameplay suit the message
votesFunny: they would make the gameplay PART OF THE STORY
commentsCount: they would use the gameplay artistically to draw in the masses and illustrate the message they want to get across. Show not tell! That's the way a good story is written! This game doesn't show me a damned thing about depression
column16: it just tells me a sob story that can easily be made happy by choosing the "Do happy thing" option whenever prompted.\n\nI give this game a 3/10. I can see what they were going for
column17: but they poorly conveyed the message they wanted to convey
column18: and removing the cornerstone of a certain type of media is never okay
column19: even if you have a poorly thought out excuse for it."

reviewText:
Before I begin, I will admit that the only reason I'm playing this game is because of the Zoe Quinn & her Five Guys scandal. And despite my feelings about infidelities, corruption of journalism, and the pack mentality of Indie Game developers, I will try to keep it out of this review.

Something I would not like to keep out of this review is my personal history with depression. I suffered for a few years, and at my worst was contemplating suicide. Seeing how this is a game about depression, I hope these experiences of mine can help with shedding light on this game.

The first thing I noticed about this game is its presentation. Though I have own a tumblr blog, I do not regularly browse tumblr or other blogging sites. However, if I did, I’m sure I’d find a striking similarity between the menus and greyed-out gifs at the tops of pages with their counterparts in tumblr blogs. I realize that this is a text-based adventure game, but for a Greenlit game I was expecting a game with more body to it. I felt like I was reading an article on the Internet, let alone engaging in a game, I wasn’t immersed.

But maybe that’s because when I was immersed I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at depression’s representation. The main character, in my first play through, goes through a downward spiral after his depression begins to take the better of him. The game represents this through staticy music and all color fading away. Granted, depression varies between individuals, and I’m sure others suffering from depression experience feelings of hopelessness and fatigue. But depression isn’t an easy thing to make a game out of without disrespecting it.

I’m competitive by nature. When I sit down and play Dark Souls or Team Fortress 2, I play to win. When I lose, I take it as a learning experience, and correct my strategy. It’s something I learned in my battle with depression. I fought, and didn’t let the common inconveniences that once disabled me slow me down further. This attitude proved useless in Depression quest, as even when I had all the chances in the world to fix my character’s problems, the game wouldn’t let me. The game wouldn’t let me do what I did in my victory over depression. It didn’t give me a chance.

I realize that many people wither under depression’s burdens without a chance of saving themselves. But a game is no place to toy with a problem that hurts millions. Depression Quest shouldn’t be played because of how it taunts a player with a chance of healing, only to cross-out the option to go to someone and get help.

A player can do a lot of amazing feats. They can save princesses, build worlds, and dominate the competition in their quests. But this is one quest that I recommend no player attempt. As a player, I was disappointed when my attitude to heal my character was worthless when the doors were already closed from the beginning. And as someone who suffered from depression, I was utterly disgusted with how a developer toys with a serious problem. Say what you will about gaming being a medium for art or a message, but this is one game that I feel is just worthless. Worthless to Indie Games, worthless to Steam, and worthless to the gaming world. Do not play this game.

reviewText:
This game isn't interesting and should have just been kept off Steam. You click hyperlinks like you're on a website. Remind me, how is reading and clicking things fun? That's the stuff I do when I do homework. Second of all, it used Robin Williams' suicide to give it a popularity boost. That was, like, the first thing they did wrong.

The story of the guy you play as doesn't even tell the story of somebody who is actually depressed. He's a spoiled white guy whose reasons for being 'depressed' is probably the developer's crappy writing and idea of a 'game'. This game wasn't designed to make people know how it feels to be depressed, it was designed for people to pick the right decision, 'win' and 'get better'. Bad things don't even seem to happen to this guy apart from the fact he's stuck in his own head.

The tags call this an RPG. There are absolutely no role-playing elements whatsoever. There is also no simulation (far from it) at all, and for some reason it was also tagged as a simulator.

Overall, I rate it five guys out of ten. Don't download this game please. It is the definition of half-♥♥♥♥♥ and its developers are attention ♥♥♥♥♥s.

reviewText: This game isn't exactly for people who are depressed, and it isn't intended to help them. Despite all the controversy regarding the developer, the game itself isn't inherently bad, and it would help you understand those who have depression better. But I don't recommend it because it's not necessary. It tells you what you already know about people who are depressed, what they do, how they act, etcetera, there's not much else to it, except for it being a nice interactive story about someone who is. If you like text-based adventure novels, go for this game, but if you want to understand depression, I can sum it up in a single sentence: I ♥♥♥♥ed five guys to censor criticism about my new game and faked attacks to myself on messaging boards to gain the sympathy of people who are ♥♥♥♥ed up like I am."\nOh

reviewText:
Just a day off of school and I scroll through this, and pick it up because I have nothing better to do.
I played through it, answering honest and what is best, and I got a generally good ending.

The game is just a story, nothing mechanical other than clicking and making games. Even though it might not be considered a game we all know and love, it is more of a novel or a little story, like a webpage comic or something. So if you were expecting a game, this might disappoint you. Steer away from this if you just want gameplay.

A person like me loves a story, and this game did well to portrait realism and a guy genuinely going through life choices that we are all destined towards to, experiencing depression and emotionall/physical exhaustion. The choices in this game chilled my spine just thinking what would happen if I clicked it. Also, there is a nice feature, which if you are depressed in a level, it won't let you make the choice, further adding realism. You can't expect a morbidly depressed guy to suddenly go up to people and say Hey guys
date: hows the weather".\n\nThe "characters" did well in their role

reviewText:
I gave this game the benefit of the doubt despite the negative reviews. I downloaded it, and with an open mind gave it a shot. After the first 14 pages of incredibly boring dialog, I had to stop reading and just start randomly choosing options. The play-through took me exactly 15 minutes. I never plan on playing this again.

How this took more than 1 person to make is beyond me. This literally could be made in html/javascript as a website, and it would still be horrible.

Anyone involved in this should seriously be ashamed of themselves, and I have no idea how anyone enjoyed this. Perhaps they are time travelers from the 80's who were only used to textbased M.U.D.S.? Even then I'm sure many of them would be dissapointed.

I wasn't before, but I am now suicidal because of this game. Thanks Zoey.

reviewText: As someone who suffers from depression myself brought on by Bipolar, I played this game with an inside knowledge of what depression is legitimately like. Not only is this game NOT a game, but it's a TERRIBLE representation of what Depression is actually like. This game reinforces terrible stereotypes about people legitimately suffering from the disease, such as that we're never happy and all we do is wallow in our own misery 24/7 with no interest in getting better, seeking treatment or taking care of ourselves. It tells people that nothing ever makes us happy ever, not even temporarily, and that all we do is lie around unable to do anything.\n\nSure, depression is brutal. Believe me I know. But this? This game is ridiculous. The only time I've ever been NEARLY as sick as the protagonist of this story" was in my extreme lows where I was borderline suicidal. But it's harmful to people who ACTUALLY suffer from depression to reinforce these horrible stereotypes. Zoe claims she wants to help fight against the stigma but all she's done was add to it. This game is further proof to me that Zoe Quinn not only doesn't care about ANYTHING she claims she does (Women's rights

reviewText:
Well...
It's not exactly easy to give this game a cheerful thumbs up amidst a sea of negative feedback from others, but this is what I believe and this is what I have to say.

Depression Quest is misunderstood. I know that sounds like an excuse, but believe me. I've clocked in one playthrough of it and in that one playthrough, more thoughts crossed my mind than any 12 hours spent on a typical shooter of your choice. In fact, I think it's wrong for me to even bring up the term 'shooter' as though in comparison because shooters are games. That's something many people who criticise this tend to complain most about. That this is a poor excuse for a game. In doing so they miss the biggest and most powerful message that this game does it's ultimate best to send.
Depression is not a game.

I've read plenty of complaints about this game from people who do have depression that found this game insulting or offensive. The last thing I, or Depression Quest, want to do is devalue those people and their experiences. But I can assure you that the opening message of the game openly admits that it's only trying to give a semblance of depression and what it's like, though they can not, in fact they can never, fully encapsulate everything about it. No two experiences of depression are the same, something the multiple choice nature of this story can only reach for. The game is honest about itself, which I think everyone at least can appreciate. It's not the be-all, end-all definition of depression. It's a taste, based on a limited experience set to try and share the pain that is experienced in the real world.

If you have depression, the game warns you beforehand what you're getting into. You may not get along with this game, which is completely okay.
As for me? I do not have depression. Nor do I understand depression. But Depression Quest did for me what it set out to do. It showed me - if only just a little - a little of what it's like. In an ironic use of the word, it's through 'play' that I'm given a bit on insight into how hopeless life can be. This is a game that teaches and shares. It might not be music that resonates with you, but the important thing is that it's heard. And I heard it.
Another complaint I've read is that your 'character' has no personality and is an empty protagonist. Again, something has been missed. This is a game told through written 2nd-person narrative. You are the main character. This is your life that you're playing through and these are your decisions. How restricted you are is how restricted you could be if you had depression. How you're told that you're feeling is how you could be feeling if you had depression. The game is saying through it's presentation of the story and 'main character' that this could be you. This could be your life. And for some people, this is their life.
You're given choices on how to make decisions on what to do, some of which are completely inaccessable. Even though you know that it's there, you can't do it. You're told often how you feel and what your mental state is, so sometimes you'll try to do what seems like the right thing only to realise that your character is only feeling worse. You'll wonder what the right choice was, or even if there ever was a right choice to begin with. Again, not everyone faces the same kind of depression, but to see into the eyes of even one kind is... eye-opening. And regardless of how it ends, you can't simply resolve everything because, once again, this isn't a game. This is life. This is depression. This is no idealised, escapist happy ending for feeling better. This is depression awareness.

In summation, no. This game is not fun. You are not meant to have fun playing it. You are meant to think, to consider, to choose and possibly to feel. If that's not what you want, if this isn't what you're looking for, walk away. But if you're up for it, dive. Dive right in. This is less of a game and more of an experience. An experience with depression for those unenlightened to it. Even if you disagree with it and it's portrayal, that's all the more reason to try it.
I promise. Devote yourself to one playthrough and you'll come away with something meaningful. Positive or negative, this is a game that redefines what games can be and what they can live up to. This is something more games should aspire to try and perfect.

So yes. I recommend it. It's thoughtful, well-written, intricate and with the best of intentions. Above all, it's different. Even if you hate it, you should try it.

reviewText: Boring, uninspired, and a bit condescending. Depression Quest isn't a game so much as a 'choose your own adventure' book in a digital format. Unfortunately, it doesn't even do that well. The story is plagued by long, boring, and bland writing. That's unfortunate because the writing is really all you see. There aren't much in the way of visuals, and navigation feels more like navigating an awkward web page than moving through a story. It tries to ram into your head that your 'character' is depressed, but it doesn't personalize the character enough to make you feel sorry for them, nor does the awkward writing make it easy to sit through all of the story. Most of the actions you choose also tend to railroad you in one single direction. It gives the illusion of variation where the reality is that it is severely lacking in that department.\n\nOverall, I do not recommend this game. I can't even begin to give this a score because it's not really a game, and even the experience it means to give you fails so horribly that trying to give it a */10 score is like trying to score a trainwreck.

reviewText:
Note: Before anyone goes and starts a flame, keep in mind this is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review, and I feel like I need to get the point across that this game does NOTHING to address actual depression.
Long story short, I don't recommend. Not because it isn't actually a game, but for the tremendously unrealistic portrait of a depressed person. To put it bluntly, this does not seem like a depressed individual who you control in the story, but a socially awkward, self-loathing, well, ♥♥♥♥♥. I don't mean to say people with depression are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because they aren't, don't put those words in my mouth. I'm saying that this guy, who has a girlfriend who loves him; a job that, in spite of his hatred of it, pays well enough for him to be comfortable; a family that loves and cares about him, and who constantly are trying to help and support him through it; and a ♥♥♥♥ING KITTEN (No, I'm not kidding) manages to still just be a mope about everything. Thats not depression my friend, thats called a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ attitude. Which is ok, I have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ attitude towards most things. But the point is, the main character is a tremendous ♥♥♥♥♥. And the people who suffer from depression related to a.)substance abuse b.)abuse in general or c.)real, actual problems in their lives that create stress are amazing people for sticking it out and I suggest they seek help etc. But if you have a girlfriend, loving family, a supporting job that gets you by, and a KITTEN, thats a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, rotten attitude you got there friend.

Should be called ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Attitude Quest"
0.5/10
(I gave it .5 points because I have a soft spot for kittens.)"

reviewText: I cannot give this a thumbs up because to me it is not a game. The options bottle neck you as it should, that being what depression does, the characters sometimes feel blank. Lack of pictures help focus on the literature but it makes it less game, the options given feel a bit wrong but as it is relatively accurate I can't complain. It shouldn't have been sold as a game or reviewed as a game and definitely doesn't deserve being on Steam. There's better books, and better things in its style but for the price of free it's definitely good. It should not be on Steam and did not deserve the reviews it got from gaming magazines and other game related companies. 6/10 bookish thing, 0/10 game.

reviewText:
I'm sad that Five Guys Burgers and Fries was tied to this. They didn't ask for this.

Though on the game here's what I think:

I won't go on about how the text is uninteresting, etc. or that your  options are always left and right,  even though the door on the left is a hallway to the right.

The game was so unengaging, that you don't have to worry about being called a sociopath if you didn't care about what happened to the character. A man in the prime of his life, with a girlfriend, friends, a job, and his own place. That's a lot more than I have, and I'm not complaining with what I do, So why's this guy upset? I guess what I'm trying to say is: This guy has no reason to complain, he's got a mate and lads to hang out with, a job, etc. so what's his deal? The thing with depression is: There's always some sort of underlying cause, and one is never given in the game. How do I sympathize with someone who hasn't a tale to his struggle? There's no sign of social distress, or infidelity (Which would be ironic in a Zoey Quinn game) no past history to go off of to see that the character has a reason to be depressed. And that's the thing: He doesn't. You quickly realize that the character is unsuitable to represent depression, or at least a common form. The Developer's chosen the MOST UNLIKELY SCENARIO to give someone depression, and that's why I can't feel a connection.

There's more I'd say, but I've decided to refrain.

TL;DR? Succinctly: It's kind of like a mid-life crisis ten+ years too early.

reviewText:
The question you propably have if you haven't played this propably is: ''is this game good?''. Here is a better one: ''is this a game?'' The answer to both questions is no IMO. Why? Cause it is just a mediocre book. There is no gameplay and no graphics. There is no reason to play it over so many wonderful free games on steam.

Let me cut this game apart in steps.

1: No gameplay: Gameplay makes a game, and this one does not even have incomplete controls. It is just a book with some options, there is no gameplay that keeps you excited. It is just not there.

2: The story is stupid: Who makes a game about a girl who is despressed and you need to help her get rid of that depression. To me, that is not a good idea for a game (but this is not a game anyway). For a game that tries to sell itself as immersive, the poor writing and the long walls of uninteresting text just make me want to skip it all.

3: It is not fun: I know that at the beginning it says that ''it is not meant to be fun'', but fun is the thing that makes a game good for me. Even technically bad games will be liked by me if they have a good fun factor. But this one does not even try, and it is not hard to see. It is so boring, its only use would be as a tool to help you sleep. If you want to read a book, THEN READ A F*CKING BOOK.

4: The developer: This is a thing that keeps coming to my mind when i think about this 'game'. You see all of those reviews saying it is a great game? Well the 'game' itself did not do anything to create these positive reviews. Rather the developer had sex with the reviewers and they had to pay her in a good review for her game, i am not kidding.... look here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C5-51PfwI3M#t=209 all credit to InternetAristocrat for making it. It is just stupid, and also why the reviews are lies. Developer Zoe Quinn....... you should be ashamed of yourself.

Those are mayor reasons why this is not a good game, or a game for that matter. There are many good and free games, please do not waste time on this one. And you may call me a hypocrite for wasting 7 minutes on it (it felt much longer), but now i experienced it and i want no more..... ever.

The End.

reviewText: It's a game. Thats the only real positive thing I can say about it. As far as a simulator goes it is very poorly designed and written out. The right and wrong choices are painfully obvious so theres no real trial and error to play. Besides that the choices that would actually help you get out of depression are all blocked, as if everyone with depression has zero mental willpower to try and help themselves. Overall my experience with this game has been very depressing indeed, the biggest letdown was the fact there was no suicidal option on the panels, as well as the fact the piano music was driving me insane to the point I had to turn off my speakers and risk not hearing the inevitable gunshot. I would not recommend this game as one to play seriously, but more as to show friends how bad it is.

reviewText:
Maybe I experienced the game differently. I definitely thought the protag was whiny and the writing was a bit pretentious, but I didn't get the sense that the game was making them out to be lazy and selfless, more that the depression was crippling their motivation and made it hard to find interest in the things they normally do.

For people saying that all the positive choices were crossed out, yes, the most helpful ones were, but there were still positive choices (usually the second option - this game has a tendency to list options in order of most-to-least helpful with a few switch-ups thrown in now-and-then, which I find a bit weird but w/e). I managed to get what I believe is the best ending (my protag was seeing a therapist, taking medication, and they weren't depressed anymore), so maybe it's just that I took the time to read the choices and think about what would be most helpful.

For those saying it's too long/too much reading, come on. It took me maybe 20 - 30 minutes to play this game and I only skimmed like 5% of the text.

I've never been officially diagnosed with depression and I don't think I have it, so I can't speak to the accuracy of the depiction in this. I'll simply say, take it with a grain of salt. You may relate to it, you may not. This game doesn't suit everyone. I liked it, but hey, that's just me. Experience the game for yourself if you want to have an opinion on it. Or don't. It doesn't matter.

reviewText:
Boring as all holy hell, railroaded to a bland ending, bland character and story progression.
The music is dull and repetitive, with one song in the soundtrack. I keep seeing people compare this to choose your own adventure books, and that's insulting, the writers of stories like the Fighting Fantasy series put effort into their games. This game looks like a 90s website, with the artwork being pictures they most likely got on a google image search.
They claim this is a learning experience, I knew nothing about clinical depression before playing, I still know jack ♥♥♥♥. The character comes off more as a whining little turd than anything else, he's got lots of friends, a girlfriend, and job that he says right at the beginning he's been rising through the ranks quickly. He's got more than many people who don't mope and ♥♥♥♥♥ about their life. Then, when he gets to doing something about his problem, it takes half a year to get it under control; Damn that's fast!
Looking at the posted official reviews on their Steam page, I see three gaming sites whose word I will never trust. Not just the game is unpleasant though, the developers are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. I dared to make a snarky discussion post and it took about an hour for them to ban my discussion. They are actively censoring criticism where they can, and I'll probably be accused of being a mysoginist for saying this game sucks.
Also, a lot of the other reviews are making me hungry, I'm going to Five Guys.
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText: What’s my verdict on Depression Quest? The game isn’t quite a game. I’m not even sure what to call this. A short story, maybe? An adventure novel? It might even be too short to be considered an adventure novel. I’m not really sure why this is on Steam. Unless Steam is soon deciding that branching out into short stories is a good idea, this isn’t a game, and it’s categorized as one, so why is it here? It’s a “hit next” simulator at best. The ability to convey depression through Depression Quest is something that only the worst of game developers could master. The experience was so horrible, not by the content that they included to intentionally make me feel horrible — no, by the lack of content that was greatly overlooked by these “game developers”. Game review? This was more of a “short story” review, but I hear 5 guys out of 10 loved it. Me? I’ll keep my integrity: Zoe Quinn’s monstrosity was the worst game that I have ever played.

reviewText: First time I played Depression Quest (about a year ago now), I wasn't doing too well mentally. I didn't want to admit anything was wrong to the people around me and felt shameful about many parts of myself. At some point, I came across the game, made by a few indie developers I hadn't heard of before, and decided to give it a shot.\n\nOf all of the games I've played, this one has had the biggest impact on my life. It managed to show me that, just maybe, what I was experiencing in my head wasn't normal"
date: but neither did I need to feel ashamed about it. I've since sought out professional help and I'm dealing with my mental issues much better.\n\nThis game may or may not be for you. It is not a fun game - don't expect to come out all smiles. Some even say it's not a game (not me
recommended: although I can understand their point based on their definition of the word). If you're easily triggered by stories or discussions about depression
hoursPlayed: I recommend avoiding playing it if you're trying to stay in a positive mood.\n\nHowever
voteText: if you're looking for an understanding of what depression is like
helpfulPercent: to help you understand what someone else might be going through... or even yourself
votesHelpful: this game offers a perspective. It is not the be all or end all of descriptions of what it is like - for sure
votesTotal: some parts of the game's perspective differ from my own experiences with depression - but if you're looking for a starting place to help you develop that understanding
votesFunny: this game is worth a try."

reviewText: This is definitely not a happy game, but for those who have depression, it really hits home. Several times I couldn't help but see the parallels between the narrator's thoughts and mine. Just like the game does, I'll have to warn those with severe depression that some moments could possibly be triggering. Just like real life, Depression Quest doesn't really have an ending, more of a reflection of the choices you made and the people you reached out to. Yes, some endings are more hopeful than others, but overall, I think Depression Quest did a great job of getting inside the head of someone who is stuck in an endless cycle, not sure how to get out. However, it also teaches you that while you may not make a lot of money or save the world, sometimes it's the little things that make life worthwhile.

reviewText: The problem with Depression Quest is that it attempts to capture an entire mental illness yet only SPECIFICALLY focuses on one specific person's journey with it. Everyone's handle of depression is different, and this game does not capture the journey well. It captures a journey, but it's so focused, so narrow that it feels like the developers made it for themselves.

reviewText: Wow, the recent uptick in negative, derogatory, and just plain abusive reviews of Depression Quest is SO BIZARRE! It's almost as if a bunch of folks with more free time than common sense got together and decided to flood the reviews! But that's crazy talk, right? Anyway, I thought this game was a thoughtful experience, accurate to many of the things people with depression have to face. Highly recommended, but only if you have enough empathy to consider someone else's point of view, listen to someone else's experiences and try to learn something from them. If not, the game's probably not gonna be your thing.

reviewText:
I'll be blunt about this terrible game as I haven't had any relationships with it's developer - unlike some of the authors behind some of the reviews on this. This is as much as a game as reading a .pdf file with all the 'interaction' being the tools up top. This is as much as a game as reading a website from 1999 and seeing all the .gif buttons lead you through the website. Shucks, maybe this is actually the next revolutional game and I'm too happy to even understand it.

I don't know, and I couldn't give any more ideas or opinions on it because I had barely played it to realize that there are people on the Greenlight who get ignored and spit on, but hey, at least they spent actual effort, right? They didn't have to do some dirty work just to get it through to several outlets where it's authors' opinions are one's people might actually listen to. They spent actual work onto it, dreaming of being into the industry one day. In this day and age of things like Game Maker and YouTube handing out free tutorials, all you really need is ambition and determination. Clearly, making a game like this had neither.

In short, this game is a load of ♥♥♥, and I want you to play it! Do YOU have a 2k Gaming PC, a good relationship, great social life, a job that makes you financially stable, great family, and possibly even more that makes you smile in the morning? Good! Then install this game, and finally experience what the people below your status experience on occasion. Feel the darkness indulge within your body, and conjure it through your black-painted finger tips. Have fun! :)

reviewText:
This game made me horribly depressed. I almost could feel like my blood was freezing as I read each line of the text. I couldn't take it, the intensity of the game began to progress, and I was instantly immersed into this rather grotesque and thrilling game. I began to feel strange, and my fingers tingled. I felt sad, and stressed, I couldn't control my emotion.

I instinctivly reached for my machete, moping in a pool of my own tears, staring at the moon-light, glistening amongst the many blades infront of me. I raised the machete, and swung it down, removing my left arm, feeling graciously free'd of my depression.

I then raised the blade, and pierced it through my now, black and dark heart.

I recommend this game to any true emo person, it's truley estonishing.


PS. I came back from the dead to write this review, I am probably dead again by the time you have read this.


-Sociopath.

reviewText:
This is a really good game. It successfully emulates what it is like to be depressed. If you can immerse yourself in this game you can find you self living or even re-living a very realistic situation that is definitely worth the experience (assuming this won't serve as some sort of trigger for you).

The only downside is that if you don't get yourself immersed, you can play very gamey-like and just hit the common-sense choices to get the happy ending.

If you do like to get immersed into a good story however I would definitely recommend this for you. I loved it.

reviewText: So it was 5:30 am for me on a tuesday morning when i stumbled across a artistic beauty of a game called Depression Quest. Through the expansion of my journey i found that the game was to teach and give players a feel of what its like to have Depressioon. Upon downloading and launching the game I was ever so graciously greeted with a (not responding)" message that some games naturally have upon launch. Once i had reached the title screen i was intruduced to the most enlightening piano music i have possibly ever heard in my life. Instinctively I started playing skipping the controls and other useless information. The first page alone had way to much dialogue so naturally i was all "wow nope" and went straight to the options. Then I proceded to dump my girl friend Alex so i could oficially be a lonely cat man. I then decided that my love for cats was greater than that of myself. reviewText: I loved this game. It made me feel more emotions than any other game I've ever played. I have struggled with depression and it is comforting to me that there is a game that shows how difficult it is to live with depression. Many people who don't understand what it is like to be depressed don't know how to help or understand someone who is lives with it. I actually had my boyfriend play it even though he was against it at the beginning because there was a lot of reading. But when he finished we talked about it and I think he got a lot out of it. It's hard to live with me sometimes when I get down but he's always there for me and I think Depression Quest can help him know more how I feel. I liked how there would always be a normal" response to a situation but it would have a line crossed out and you weren't able to pick it. That's just like real life. You know what you should feel like or what you should be doing but you just can't do it. It's just not possible. That also is a great way to show people who don't suffer what it feels like. I always tried making the best decision possible when I played. Again
date: I know what it's like to be depressed and I always try to see the best in life even when it's really hard to do so. I think it should be manditory for everyone to play this game.\n\n"

reviewText: As a 22 year old who has suffered depression as long as he can remember (as far back as age 5) I can attest to the accuracy of the main character's emotions in this story. The way the main character overthinks things, beats himself up over large and small mistakes alike, runs through possible scenarios in his head, only causing himself to worry more - I have experienced all of this. Also, too many times do I hear people telling me to cheer up" or "get over it
date: but they just don't understand... it's not that easy - I don't want to be depressed, if it were just a mindset, I would have stopped being depressed long ago. Although many situations in this story I have not experienced (I've never had a girlfriend, or seen a therapist) I can still relate to how the main character feels throughout - the narrative is very thorough, and thus is very effective at portraying the situation, making it easy for me to put myself in his shoes. The choices are well varied, and I always found at least one option that I would do in that situation. After completing the game, I came to what seemed to me to be the best ending. Too bad it's just a game.\n\nBy the way, it's funny how many bad reviews this game got by people who aren't depressed, saying, it's not realistic" when they are the target audience
hoursPlayed: a depressed person writing a review gave a positive one saying that it is realistic."

reviewText:
Cons:

- Writing is a bit boring.
- Soundtrack is monotonous.
- Lots of plot but no characterization.
- The three “status bars” make it obvious what you need to do to get the good ending.

Pros:
- It ultimately gives a good message: if you feel depressed, seek help from friends, family and / or doctors.
- It’s a free game.

For a better executed game tackling intimate subjects, I recommend Coming Out Simulator 2014. It’s better written, more visually stimulating and has a story with a bigger impact. And it’s also free.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Don't mistake this for a game. It is not. It is a piece of propaganda designed to drive home that depression is a hopeless condition.

What annoys me the most is that there are no real choices presented. Any meaningful way to improve your character is vividly struck out in red, to underline that it is hopeless. This is a huge lie-  there are genuine sufferers of depression who do make an effort to and do overcome their condition. They do select the red choices and make things better for themselves.

This game does a great disservice to genuine sufferers of depression who may be led to believe the message that all is hopeless. I worry that it might just tip them into seeking a permanent solution. If you have any remotely depressed friends, DO NOT let them play this 'game'. I cannot stress this enough.

And I cannot understand why the developers have chosen to preach such a bleak (and untrue!) message instead of one carrying some hope for depressives. This is bordering on, if not outright irresponsible.

reviewText: First of all, if you want to make a game about real issues, make it an actual game for christ's sake. The story is nonexistant with no coherent plot, no meaningful dialogue, and not a single choice the player makes has any real impact on the outcome of the story. This alleged game is not educational, its not interesting, its not artistic, and it is not in any way shape or form GOOD. The protagonist is a cardstock shell. The player is hard pressed to even remotely connect with [him]  in any way. If the intent behind making this game was to spread awareness about depression, help people with depression, or even educate the player about depression, you've ♥♥♥♥ing failed miserably. Without any trace of a story or even an ounce of entertaining gameplay, this game failed to deliver an ounce of education, entertainment, or amusement. If you want to learn about depression or various other mental illnesses tumblr users diagnose themselves with, you might as well read any text post written by some SJW ♥♥♥♥. If you want to learn about the effects of depression on a real person, this game is not for you. If you have a pulse, this game is not for you.

reviewText:
I've played this before on the interwebs. Might as well toss out a token review.
For a game that causes grown men to go into fits over the dreaded ess-jay-dubyas, this isn't a terrible intersectional game. The main character doesn't have any money concerns, has a steady job, a supportive girlfriend and at least one supportive family member, hits the jackpot on their first time visiting a therapist (it took me about four or five tries to find one that clicked), lives in a location that allows them to keep a cat, and doesn't seem to suffer any ill effects from race, religion, physical disability, age, or gender.
As a long-time sufferer of depression's smaller cousin, dysthymia (if depression is a big black dog sitting on your chest for stretches of time, dysthymia is an overweight cat that lays on your head and never leaves), I recognized a lot of the situations presented in the game, and the options for action described pretty well actions I might have taken. Although I really wish getting help were as easy as clicking a link in a Twine game...
All in all this game doesn't merit the hate it gets. So thusly I give it a recommendation. It's not a Half-Life-esque landmark game... but it deserves to be appreciated for what it is.
I hope that somewhere, somehow, thisgame  makes a grown man-child dudebro cry. I hope it makes him recognize depression in himself or someone he loves. I hope he can become a better person because of it. I hope like hell.

reviewText:
If you are unfamiliar with depression, or know someone suffering with depression, play this to get an idea of how they may feel and how hard it is for them to do certain kinds of things. I love seeing unique experiences on Steam. My hat goes off to the developer for releasing the game free to reach as many as possible.

Depression Quest is an interactive text novel  where you read real-life examples of how someone with depression feels and then try to select the best answer for him. Depending on how depressed your character currently is some answers are crossed out/unavailable such as Hunker down and get to work". This helps those unfamiliar with depression to get an idea of how debilitating depression is.

You can tell a lot of time and attention to detail has been put into this game. The music changes to match how your choices are affecting the characters depression and the graphics on each story page also change."

reviewText: This game is just... ugh. Despite it's good intentions, it manages to depict sufferers of depression as whiny, angst ridden people content to live in their misery, which i know for a fact is not true. As I played through, I tried my damndest to get my character help, but every attempt to open up to somebody or to pursue help led nowhere. Beyond that, the supposed choices the game offers are a lie. Every single choice you make leads you to exactly ONE alternate snatch of text, and then directly back to a screen which you'd have wound up on if you had made any other choice. On top of that, the game does NOT tell a cohesive story, with a beginning, middle, and end. out of nowhere, you get a screen explaining to you that it didn't have an ending, because depression never ends (oh I see, it's completely insurmountable, good to know).\n\nI could forgive all of this if the game was simply able to cause me to empathize with sufferers of depression, but in that, and many other regards, it utterly fails. The people heralding this as a grand artistic step for video games absolutely baffle me. The writing reads like the kind of stuff a high schooler might write, and the scope of the game is surprisingly limited, even considering the small development team. Don't give this game your time.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed playing Depression Quest. I believe it had a respectful perspective of depression, and used classical text-adventure game mechanics as an appropriate delivery method. Depression is a sensitive subject that can be explored in a variety of ways, and the creators appear sensitive to the potential consequences of 'gamifying' depression. The music and evolving background ambience enhanced the experience. The strike-out progression options add to the atmosphere of futility, that no action ever feels like the right action, because the right action is always present but unavailable.

I really saw a lot of potential for the link-to-additional-info buttons in the first screen of the game, and believe the experience would have been improved by continued use of that mechanic. I'd like to see more interactive stories with drill-down narratives like this; it's an inspiring piece of functionality that allows an author to provide supplemental details for those who crave a deeper narrative.

While I enjoyed the three Status boxes for emotional well-being, therapy and medication, I felt that these may have felt too much like direct goal indicators. I believe it would have been beneficial to expose this information only upon receiving therapy or medication. While the player may be aware that these statuses represent treatment for depression, my gamer-brain interprets their immediate presence as goals for success. However, the narrative clearly indicates that the player character did not consider the benefits of seeking help.

The game provided key triggers that lead to introspection of my own depression as well as the depression of my family members. I felt the game succeeds very strongly in its ability to trigger introspective thought. I was particularly moved by the scenes in which Mom presses for career progression and inspects" the player's life
date: as well as the scenes in which the player struggles with the negative-feedback loop associated with job dissatisfaction. Alex
hoursPlayed: and attic's support not only reminded me of the support I've received
voteText: but also reminds me to be supportive of those I care about.\n\nAs a take-away
helpfulPercent: it's important to remember to be empathetic of those facing depression
votesHelpful: and to be cognizant of signs that they may be in "one of those moods." It can be difficult not to fall into Mom's aggressive encouragement
votesTotal: and so the game inspires me to be more reflective on my own impatience with others' depression."

reviewText:
The game leaves you with a heavy feeling in your heart, but that's exactly what the developers were aiming for. They told from the very beginning that it wouldn't be a pleasant expirience, and it wasn't. But I think they achieved their goal - show  the player how people with heavy depression feel.

I see two minuses in the game:
1. It won't start from Steam menu, and I had to launch the .exe file from the game folder. Not a big deal, but this technical flaw spoils the impression a bit.
2. No saves. The game is really short, but the fact that you have to beat it in one run makes you hurry a bit and doesn't allow you to feel the story as deeply as you could.

I think it would be useful for everybody to get acquainted with this game, because it can help you to understand how somebody near you feels, and how to better help him/her.

reviewText: Depression Quest manages to convey a believable sense of what one might experience, living through daily life with depression.  While it won't capture everyone's experience with the illness, it can certainly serve to allow players who haven't experienced depression to imagine what others go through better.\n\nOn a mechanical level, Depression Quest is also interesting in the realm of interactive fiction in the way it tracks your character's mental health, and presents choices which may be disallowed because of your character's illness.  An interesting study on the power of the *illusion* of choice (or at least, the frustration of missed opportunity, even if certain options are never allowed to be chosen).

reviewText: Zoe Quinns new game depresion quest features a 62 year old black women suffering from post traumatic stress disorder. The reason for this being her fathers sexuall abuse towards her as a child and that her man took away her watermellon, fried chicken, and big loop earings. She is now trying to overcome her fears of those dank gangsters finding her by meeting with the peesos, a group of mexican gangsters who specialize in drug and weapons trafficing to america. In the company of these gangsters she learns how to use firearms, make many different kinds of hallucinogenic drugs, and then becomes a very sucsessful drug dealer and rises through the ranks of the peesos. But one day she loses it all when her mans gang, the sharqueshans, attack the peesos at their heart. She survives, but her mind and soul are left broken and she dosent know what to do. Throught a series of unfortunate events ends up with one broken leg, in the middle of pakistan. Affter sucsesfully hijacking a US military convoy she finds herself in the pilots seat of a C-130 headed for america. reviewText:
An interesting and short game about living with depression.

More of a choose-your-own-adventure story, it manages to capture the futility and worthlessness associated with the disease. Kudus to the desiger and writers.

(My only minor quibble is with the emphasis on social anxiety. While depression and anxiety are usually concomitant, that doesn't inherently mean a depressed person will be socially anxious.)

reviewText:
A quiet and honest look at the emotional resonance that games can have. Even if they have to let go of the concept of fun to do it.

This game doesn't have win-lose scenarios, an obvious best choice, or even a guarnteed resolution. All it has is realistic decisions based on the story's current circumstances. It plays with exceptations the same way reality does.

While I've only played through the game once, I managed to get a personal ending that I felt was appropriate for the story (out of the possibilities of 150 possible encounters). If you ask me, it was pretty close to the best ending, but I felt like I didn't always make the right choices. Just honest answers.

And rule of thumb: the first choice isn't always the best choice.

Plus it's free and takes about 20-30 minutes of reading (at my reading speed).

If you can spare that time, then I guarantee that this game deserves to be played once; and you deserve to understand that depression is always a possibility, but never an eventuality. So remember what this game offered. As a fellow human, it is the best that you can do.

Sincerely,

R.B.

reviewText: As much as I want to enjoy this game, for the sake of abandoning bias, Depression Quest is undeniably a boring game. While the game is obviously designed to make the player feel helpless, the method of achieving such a feeling is awkward at best and dysfunctional at worst; The Player does not take the role of the protagonist or understand the protagonist, but rather feels agitated by the lack of control of the protagonist (For this reason, I especially do not recommend Depression Quest to those suffering from Clinical Depression).\n\nYou know you've failed in your work when an MS paint comic (Hyperbole and a Half) made by one person better conveys the concept of clinical depression than an Interactive Fiction made by three people.

reviewText: I just want to know why you can't kill yourself?? The warning at the beginning mentions suicide as a trigger, so why isn't that even mentioned by the character? If you want to make a more realistic game about depression, at least give the option to kill yourself. Sure that's not what EVERY depressed person contemplates, but had a content warning for it, so what's the problem? When nameless-MC is so deeply depressed he can't get out of bed 90% of the time, why can he not kill himself. Why. Regardless of what's right or wrong or whatever, it's reality.\n\nBut that aside, I found it to be pretty accurate for depression- at least for the way I experience it. I'm probably just griping about the suicide option because that's the main difference between the depression depicted here and my personal depression, because no matter how good I feel I still want to die. I realize that this game was based on the creators' experience with depression, but I find the trigger warning to be out of place. I did a playthrough making the worst possible choices to see if he could off himself, and it was hardly different than if he was happy, save for the fact that MC was spending a buttload of money on therapy and medications on the happiest route. There should be a more drastic difference between the endings to show just how much a few decisions can make someone's life pan out differently.
